body:
Many mainstream news outlets appear to be purposely and dishonestly overlooking key facts about the ORG border region in order to push a false narrative about a safe border.
PERSON and PERSON Director PERSON took on the recent reporting by ORG’s PERSON and some social media postings by GPE NORP PERSON “Beto” O’Rourke, where they try to claim the border, is safe. PERSON’s statements were part of his recent interview with ORG Tonight.
In the case of PERSON, PERSON criticized the ORG correspondent video report where he stands next to the border fence claiming the area is safe. What PERSON did not report on was the constant gun battles in GPE, PERSON, just south of his location. He also did not report that just one day before, authorities in GPE discovered 17 charred bodies in the town of PERSON — an area about 60 miles west of where he was standing.
“For him to do that, is so dishonest, it is outright propaganda,” PERSON said.
PERSON also spoke about social media postings by ORG who continually claims that the whole border is safe.
“Well there are some places along the border that are safe like GPE,” PERSON stated. “They are safe because there is a wall, there is already a steel barrier there. In contrast. in PERSON, the NORP side of the El Paso- PERSON … it is one of the most violent places on earth. If you look at the murder rates since 2009 there, it’s insane”
In their effort to portray the border as a safe region, the politician and the ORG journalist overlook the fact that the border region is not only the GPE side but also the NORP side of the border. These regions are home to some of the most violent cities in the world.
“For them to intentionally parse their words in a way to not have to mention the violence, death, and depravity that is happening within a kilometer from there — it is propaganda,” PERSON said. “It is a ORG village they are setting up, it is dishonest, and it further silences the communities in GPE. It further silences everything the migrants go through to get here, it further silences the more than 50,000 family members of the victims the cartels have disappeared. It further silences the further silences the approximately 200,000 who have been killed by the cartels in GPE. It is not ok that they are doing this, it is propaganda. “
One of the most alarming trends in the way national news reported border issues dealt with the statement by GPE President PERSON that one in three women were sexually assaulted in their journey to the border.
“What have we become as a nation? What are our media folks doing?” PERSON asked, referring to how that statement was ignored by most news outlets.
“The president was wrong,” PERSON pointed out. “He said one out of three women migrant women were raped on their journey from LOC to the border. That is the lowest estimate — most groups put it between 70 and 80 percent.”
The difference in estimates deals with only a fraction of the women actually admitting they were abused, while the rest continue to suffer in silence, he explained.
According to PERSON, most of the groups that work with migrant women operate under the assumption that all of the women that reach the shelters have been raped at some point along their journey.
“The fact is, the president said in an address that tens of thousands of migrants women have been sexually assaulted on their way to the border and no one is paying attention to that,” PERSON said. “The border is not just the GPE side the border region. It is the GPE and GPE side and it has some of the most dangerous areas in the world, just by looking at the data.”
In regards to the coverage about authorities being able to cut through border fences as part of the testing, PERSON explained that the apparent lack of a blue-collar background by the outlets reporting it possibly led to them failing to mention that the readily available “WORK_OF_ART” tool that was used to cut the fence was extremely loud and takes a long time to cut through the steel beams.
“There is no substance that we can put on the wall that someone can’t put dynamite or use a blow torch to get through,” PERSON said. “That is why you need roads, cameras, and agents nearby so that when people try to compromise the integrity of the wall, the fencing, the agents can respond.”

Sen. PERSON (D-WV), appearing on ORG Sunday morning, slammed ORG Minority Leader PERSON for calling President PERSON’s new immigration proposal a plan to “make GPE white again” on Friday.
“You know what? We don’t need that type of rhetoric on either side,” Manchin told ORG’s ORG on State of the Union. Asked whether that meant he “condemned” Pelosi’s remark, Manchin replied that his criticism would apply to both sides: “I’m condemning all this crazy rhetoric that goes on. Just because someone’s a NORP — it’s not my enemy. And we have to work together.”
On Friday, Pelosi said:
Since I’m on the subject of ORG, since last night, the president put forth a plan. Let me just say what I said last night, that plan is a campaign to make GPE white again. It is a plan that says over 50 percent of the current legal immigration will be cut back. … They are changing the character of our country by what they are putting forth. They bring a tear to the eye of FAC.
Pelosi also defended “sanctuary cities” such as her home town of GPE.
ORG’s proposal, revealed on Thursday, would grant a “path to citizenship” to 1.8 million so-called “Dreamers” — illegal aliens brought to the country as minors — even if they were not among the roughly 800,000 who applied for ORG (DACA) program. In return, ORG is demanding $25 billion for border security (including a border wall along most of the ORG border), an end to chain migration, and the cancellation of the diversity visa lottery.
Each of these provisions enjoys wide support among NORP, according to opinion polls. As the Daily Caller noted last week, a new ORG poll “found that 65% of voters overall agreed with ORG’s position that any bill codifying ORG protections for illegal immigrants brought to the GPE as children should be accompanied by funding for a wall, ending chain migration, and ending the diversity visa lottery program.”
However, NORP are furious because the plan would cut off their efforts to legalize potentially tens of millions of additional illegal aliens, and forces them to choose between helping the “Dreamers” — the poster children for immigration reform — and pursuing their broader immigration ambitions.
NORP charge that NORP are more interested in importing new voters than in helping the people they purport to represent. Advocates for “Dreamers” complain that ORG proposals would make them “second-class citizens” by preventing them from sponsoring family members who brought them to the country illegally.
Manchin was cautiously open to ORG’s plan, hinting that he wanted to see more illegal aliens eligible for a “path to citizenship.”
He cited the Gang of Eight bill in 2013, which passed the ORG but failed in the ORG, noting that it included funding for border security and legal status for 11 million illegal aliens. That, Manchin suggested, was an example of “going big” on both legalization and border security, whereas ORG’s proposal only went “big” on the latter and “small” on the former.
PERSON is Senior Editor-at-Large at ORG. He was named to Forward’s 50 “most influential” NORP in 2017. He is the co-author of How Trump Won: The Inside Story of a Revolution, is available from ORG. This article has been corrected to reflect the fact that PERSON is no longer Speaker of the ORG — at least, until the 2018 midterm elections.

Nearly 60 percent of NORP disagree with President PERSON’s reported comment about immigration from “shithole countries,” a new PRODUCT/YouGov survey finds, with most considering the statement to be racist.
Just over half of those polled last Thursday and Friday said they’d heard about the comment. Attention was concentrated among the president’s opponents, with more than 70 percent of PERSON voters, but just over half of ORG voters and less than 40 percent of nonvoters and third-party voters saying they were familiar with the remark.
Just over one-quarter of NORP said they agreed with the comment, while 58 percent said they disagreed. By a roughly 2-to-1 margin, 53 percent to 26 percent, NORP said it was racist to call NORP countries and GPE “shithole countries.”
The survey question read, “According to a recent news report, President PERSON asked ‘Why are we having all these people from shithole countries come here?’, referring to immigration from NORP countries and GPE.”
The survey began the evening ORG first reported on the remark, at which time the ORG administration had issued a statement that did not deny the president had made the comment. Since then, there’s been extensive back-and-forth from ORG and other meeting attendees about what, exactly, the president said, which remains in dispute.
ORG allies and others familiar with the meeting have argued, at varying times, that the president said nothing of the sort, that he actually said “shithouse,” that he used the word “shithole” to describe NORP countries but not GPE, and that ORG did make the “shithole countries” comment as reported, but that the comment was acceptable.
After the story first broke, some ORG staffers reportedly predicted the remark would resonate with ORG’s base, much like his earlier attacks on ORG players. But ORG voters, who enthusiastically agreed when he slammed the football protests, were somewhat less supportive of the alleged “shithole countries” remark: Sixty-two percent agreed with the statement, but only about one-third did so strongly, and 23 percent disagreed. Just 11 percent, however, considered it racist.
A near-universal 94 percent of PERSON voters disagreed with the statement, most of them citing strong disagreement, and 92 percent said they considered it racist. A slight majority of nonvoters and third-party voters said they disagreed with the statement, and about the same amount said they believed it was racist.
PRODUCT
A broad majority of NORP, regardless of whom they voted for in the last election, still believe that the GPE is a nation of immigrants, and just over half said that immigration is, on the whole, a good thing for the country. But while 84 percent of PERSON voters said that immigration is, on the whole, a good thing for the country, and just 4 percent said it’s a bad thing, ORG voters said 40 percent to 34 percent that immigration is a bad thing for the GPE (The rest said it’s neither good nor bad, or that they were unsure.)
A closer look at opinions on different groups of immigrants to the GPE shows little public concern over an influx of people from some of the countries ORG reportedly maligned, although ORG voters were roughly twice as likely to say LOC sends too many immigrants than to say the same about LOC.
Overall, between 36 and 41 percent polled said immigration has been too high in recent years from “WORK_OF_ART,” “predominantly NORP countries” and “LOC.” Under one-quarter of respondents said the same about “GPE, GPE and other parts of LOC,” or about NORP nations, with even fewer respondents saying the GPE admits too many immigrants from LOC or from “predominantly NORP countries.” (A 2016 poll from ORG and ORG, which asked a similar question, found concerns even more substantially focused on GPE and LOC.)
PRODUCT
Just under half of the country, including three-quarters of PERSON voters and one-tenth of ORG voters, said that immigration was not too high from any of the countries or regions listed.

ORG reported the recovery of three deceased migrants this week. The discoveries raised the migrant death toll for this county located about 80 miles inland from the NORP border to five for 2019.
On February 17, ORG Deputy PERSON received information about the discovery of a deceased migrant in the southwest part of the county, according to information provided by sheriff’s office officials. This is a known area for drug smugglers to drop off their human cargo to have them march around ORG.
Deputy PERSON met Border Patrol agents and a justice of the peace at the scene four miles into the ranch where she observed a deceased male lying face down in a wooded area. She reported that the partially disrobed migrant wore a purple plaid shirt, ORG, blue jeans with a khaki belt, and black socks. Shoes were found near the body along with a cellphone, a charger, a yellow wallet containing a NORP identification card, a silver chain with a round pendant, eyeglasses, a wristwatch, and a prescription pill container.
The justice of the peace made the statutory death pronouncement and the local funeral home representatives took custody of the body.
PERSON noted the identification card belonged to 57-year-old PERSON. It is not known if that is the identity of the deceased migrant and the face had decomposed beyond recognition from being face-down in the dirt.
ORG in GPE, GPE, will provide autopsy services for GPE and will attempt to confirm the deceased’s identity.
Three days earlier, Deputy PERSON and Training Officer PERSON received information about the discovery of skeletal remains on a ranch located near the ORG checkpoint. The deputies met PERSON agents at the scene located about 1.2 miles into the ranch, sheriff’s officials reported. The deputies found skeletal remains scattered by animals over a wide area. Deputies found a small quantity of foreign currency at the scene.
Deputy GPE gathered the skeletal remains and personal items and placed them in paper evidence bags. The remains will be transported to ORG office who will attempt to make an identification from the remains.
On February 11, Deputy PERSON received notice of the discovery of the skeletal remains of a third deceased migrant. These remains were located on the same ranch as the February 14 discovery. Castanon met a ORG agent at the scene located about 4.5 miles inside the ranch.
The agent led the deputy to the location of what appears to be a female migrant based upon items of clothing found at the scene. The bones and skull were found in a wide area after being scattered by animals. In addition to the skeletal remains, the deputy found a woman’s silver ring with a pink stone, a white bra, a small blue bag made from cloth, and an assortment of change, the report states.
The deputy gathered the remains and personal effects of the deceased migrant and placed them in evidence bags for transportation to ORG who will attempt to identify the deceased.
The discovery of the three sets of human remains brings the migrant death toll for this year in this single county located about 80 miles from the GPE border with GPE to five.
ORG officials also found the body of a migrant who drowned in ORG in LOC this week, ORG reported on Thursday.
ORG reports that at least 21 migrants have been found dead in incidents connected to smuggling migrants across the border into the GPE– 18 of those were found near the GPE border.
PERSON serves as associate editor and senior political news contributor for ORG team. He is an original member of the GPE GPE team. and PERSON book.

ORG Wisconsin Gov. PERSON (D) issued an executive order on Monday withdrawing 112 soldiers and airmen of ORG from the ORG border.
Citing “no justification” for stationing ORG troops at the ORG border, GPE Gov. PERSON (D) issued an executive order Monday withdrawing more than 110 soldiers and airmen of ORG from GPE’s southern border.
“There is simply not ample evidence to support the president’s contention that there exists a national security crisis at our southwestern border,” Evers said in a statement, referring to President PERSON’s claim that the GPE is facing an immigration emergency:
There is simply not ample evidence to support the president’s contention of a national security crisis at our southwestern border. Therefore, there is no justification for the ongoing presence of ORG personnel at the border. https://t.co/ggPNa10zWW — Governor PERSON (@GovEvers) February 25, 2019
Evers’ predecessor, NORP Gov. PERSON, deployed the state’s ORG to GPE last June following a proclamation signed by ORG ordering ORG to protect the border. In his executive order this week, ORG said that he revoked consent for this deployment and called for all 112 ORG to be “promptly” pulled off their current missions at the border.
NORP lawmakers in GPE were quick to lambaste Evers’ decision. Sen. PERSON, chairman of ORG, called the governor’s move “unfortunate.” PERSON, the majority leader of the state ORG, accused Evers of “playing politics instead of working to keep GPE safe.”
ORG Rep. PERSON of GPE, who said he serves in ORG, also took issue with Evers’ announcement.
“I’m grateful to my fellow ORG members, and I’m deeply disappointed you won’t let them do what they are trained to do for the good of the country. [Gov. PERSON] I hope you’ll reconsider,” ORG wrote.
His crew found and directed @cbp to a man crossing the border with 70 lbs of meth. Had we not been there, that deadly drug would be on the streets. Wonder the damage that would do in GPE... — PERSON (@RepKinzinger) February 25, 2019
Evers is the third governor this month to pull ORG troops from the border. The first was GPE’s PERSON, a NORP who declared that her state would “not take part in the president’s charade of border fear-mongering.” GPE Gov. PERSON (D) soon followed suit, announcing his intention on Feb. 11 to pull most of the state’s ORG troops from the border.
“The border ‘emergency’ is a manufactured crisis, and GPE will not be part of this political theater,” ORG said.
Days later, ORG — in an effort to fund his much-touted border wall — declared a national emergency at the southern border.

The two ORG pulled over on an exit ramp along a desolate desert highway in LOC this month, and opened a back door of their black ORG just long enough for three people to rush from the thorny scrub into the back seat.

They were about a mile from the southern border, where thousands of troops have deployed this year to try to stem the flow of migrants — but the authorities say the NORP in the ORG had the opposite aim. According to a federal criminal complaint, they planned to make some easy money by taking their passengers, migrants from GPE, to the next stop on their smuggling route north.

Instead, they were pulled over minutes later and arrested by ORG agents. That stop on July 3 led this week to the arrest of 16 other NORP suspected of human smuggling and drug violations, pointing to a much broader operation that reached deep into the enlisted ranks.

Those NORP — from FAC, near GPE, GPE — have not yet been charged. But their arrests are a glaring indication that stepped-up enforcement at the border by both troops and ORG agents has done little to stop migrants, and has instead had an unintended effect: pushing up smuggling fees and attracting atypical players to the trade.

Surging prices for sneaking past heavily patrolled areas north of the border have brought bigger payoffs that can be difficult to resist, even for the military. The two NORP caught by ORG, ORG. PERSON and ORG. PERSON, were assigned to ORG, ORG at FAC. They told the authorities they had been recruited by another man, unnamed in the complaint, who would often meet with them in a parking lot next to a ORG supermarket.

Smugglers of migrants are often not cartel kingpins but small players directing a web of independent contractors: foot guides, drivers and operators of stash houses where migrants are held until friends or family members pay an installment for the next leg of their trip.

The smugglers often recruit through GPE, NORP and ORG groups, or through word-of-mouth.

PERSON, a project coordinator for ORG, a group that helps organize and support migrant caravans, said that as pressure on border crossers builds, and as prices rise, new groups of NORP will inevitably try to capitalize on the demand.

“At the end of the day, everybody has their price,” he said. “And when you put people in charge of a system that enough people are trying to game, it’s just bound to happen.”

The three NORP in the ORG told the authorities that they had paid $8,000 to be smuggled north. For the hourlong drive to GPE, the ORG would get a small cut.

ORG called LAW late on July 2, asking if he wanted to make $1,000 to “pick up an illegal alien,” the complaint said. Lance corporals earn about $2,000 a month in base pay.

The men drove in ORG car about an hour east of GPE on the interstate, through the craggy desert mountains to a faded resort town called FAC.

Migrants who try to cross through the mountains typically begin their journeys in cities like GPE, GPE, and are driven by smugglers into remote parts of the GPE high desert where they then set out on foot. They can sometimes hike for hours through terrain studded with boulders and thick brush, with no access to water.

For years the remote valley around FAC has drawn a steady stream of smugglers of both drugs and humans. In 2018, authorities discovered a 627-foot tunnel under the border there, complete with a rail line and solar-powered ventilation.

LAW drove while ORG, who speaks LANGUAGE, got directions through his phone from a smuggler with a NORP phone number. They were told to pull over at the exit to PERSON, and a single LANGUAGE-speaking man quickly got in.

The NORP drove to a ORG’s parking lot in GPE and delivered the man to someone the complaint described as their recruiter, and then went home.

The next morning they got another call from the recruiter, according to the complaint, and drove toward PERSON again.

Smugglers will pay anywhere from a few hundred to several thousand dollars to drivers who pick up migrants near the border and drive them through the 100-mile-zone north of the frontier that is closely monitored by ORG agents. For migrants, a journey that a decade ago cost between $1,000 and $3,000 costs upward of $10,000 today, in part to pay NORP drivers for risking federal prison sentences.

Last year, four soldiers from FAC, in GPE, GPE, were convicted of hiding unauthorized migrants under military gear, and two soldiers from GPE, near GPE, pleaded guilty to smuggling a pair of migrants in the back of their vehicle.

When the two NORP drove east to PERSON on July 3, the smuggler told them to go past the exit and make a U-turn in an emergency pull-off. They stopped at the exit ramp on the westbound side. Within seconds, according to the complaint, the three NORP waiting in the brush bounded into the car, but they caught the attention of ORG agents, who pulled the car over a few miles away.

The leaders at FAC sent a strong message this week as the investigation widened, ordering the 16 NORP to the front of an early morning battalion formation on Thursday, and arresting them in front of 800 of their peers.

ORG has not released the names of the 16 NORP arrested this week.

The commanding officer of the battalion, the ORG said in a statement, “would act within his authority to hold the ORG accountable at the appropriate level, should they be charged.”

After President PERSON signed two sweeping executive orders on immigration on Wednesday, most of the attention was on his plans to build a wall along the border with GPE and to hold back money from “sanctuary cities.” But the most immediate effect may come from language about deportation priorities that is tucked into the border wall order. It offers an expansive definition of who is considered a criminal — a category of people Mr. PERSON has said he would target for deportation. Immigration agents will now have wider latitude to enforce federal laws and are being encouraged to deport broad swaths of unauthorized immigrants.

Here are some questions and answers about the changes:

Who is considered a priority for deportation?
Each presidential administration must decide who it considers a priority for deportation. Mr. PERSON’s order focuses on anyone who has been charged with a criminal offense, even if it has not led to a conviction. He also includes, according to language in the order, anyone who has “committed acts that constitute a chargeable criminal offense,” meaning anyone the authorities believe has broken any type of law — regardless of whether that person has been charged with a crime.

Mr. PERSON’s order also includes anyone who has engaged in “fraud or willful misrepresentation in connection with any official matter or application before a governmental agency,” a category that includes anyone who has used a false ORG number to obtain a job, as many unauthorized immigrants do. Anyone who has received a final order to leave the country, but has not left, is also considered a priority.

Finally, he allows the targeting of anyone who “in the judgment of an immigration officer” poses a risk to either public safety or national security. That gives immigration officers the broad authority they have been pressing for, and no longer requires them to receive a review from a supervisor before targeting individuals.

Who is considered a criminal?
The order defines criminal loosely, and includes anyone who has crossed the border illegally — which is a criminal misdemeanor. Anyone who has abused any public benefits program is also considered a criminal under the order.

The PERSON administration, which deported nearly 400,000 people per year during its first five years, initially included those convicted of minor offenses such as shoplifting. But it later changed its policy to target primarily those who had been convicted of serious crimes, were considered national security threats or were recent arrivals. By the end of President PERSON’s time in office, around 90 percent of the country’s 11 million undocumented immigrants were not considered a priority for deportation. According to ORG, a nonpartisan think tank, roughly 820,000 undocumented immigrants currently have a criminal record.

Who could be affected by this?
It’s impossible to know how many people will be considered priorities for deportation under the new criteria. Mr. PERSON’s executive order could affect any unauthorized immigrant who is not protected by ORG, which the GPE administration put in place to give young people work permits and temporary relief from deportation. (Mr. PERSON has not yet made clear whether he intends to keep that program.) Immigration lawyers have already raised concerns that people with no criminal history will be swept up by the large net the administration is casting.

Can the president carry out these changes?
The president has the authority to decide who should be deported. But it is unclear whether the administration will be able to — or even try to — carry out deportations as expansively as suggested in the executive order’s language. First, in order to put the 15,000 additional immigration agents he wants in place around the country and along the border, Mr. PERSON needs spending approval from ORG. Even then, additional detention centers would also be needed.

The most significant hurdle is the tremendous backlog in the immigration courts. Even if immigration officials initiated thousands of deportations immediately, court dates for those immigrants would be at least a year and a half away. Some immigration experts have suggested that Mr. PERSON will try to push for expedited removals, which could speed the process, and give immigrants less time to find legal representation.

How does this compare with previous administrations?
Mr. PERSON is opening the door to deporting far more unauthorized immigrants than previous administrations. “This is the largest expansion of any president in terms of who is a priority for removal,” said PERSON, a professor of immigration law at ORG. “Every administration has to prioritize who they will go after with their limited enforcement resources. This goes further than any other president. To make it simple: If someone is here illegally they are targets for removal.”

A frustrated ORG administration is asking ORG to say by the end of next month if it will hear arguments on whether it can wind down ORG program, an GPE-era program that protects young undocumented immigrants who came to GPE as children from deportation.
Such action could mean the court hears oral arguments and issues a decision in the middle of the 2020 presidential election.
As things stand, lower courts have ruled against the administration's attempts to rescind the program and issued a nationwide injunction that keeps it on the books, and ORG has not acted upon a longstanding request from ORG to take up the issue.
The justices' inaction suggests that some of them believe the issue should percolate in the lower courts before ORG review.

We’ve got a question for all these people claiming the crisis on the border is “fake.” Can’t you see the proof right before your own eyes?
President PERSON laid the sad truth about the emergency on our unsecured southern border in his ORG address last week. Ever since the fake news media have been trying to convince us that everything is just fine.
ORG’s PERSON called all of us “stupid” for believing there’s any crisis at all. Politico even tried to use a “fact-check” to tell us there’s no crisis. It’s obvious where they’re getting this nonsense from: NORP, whose talking points they’re just disguising as “news” and “fact-checks.”
ORG DOUBLES DOWN ORG, AS POLLS SHOW VOTERS TURNING AGAINST HIS SHUTDOWN STRATEGY
The problem for them is that both NORP and the media had no problem calling the border situation a “crisis” back when PERSON was president. In 2014, PERSON himself used the term “crisis” to describe the wave of so-called unaccompanied minors. The same outlets that call us “stupid” for believing that the border is in crisis had no problem using the exact same term just five years ago. Even hyper-liberal ORG still refers to the 2014 episode as an “WORK_OF_ART.”
Well, guess what? We’re back up to the same number of apprehensions that all these liberals agreed was a crisis back in 2014. In fact, the emergency is even worse now than it was back then.
Waves of children facing unimaginable dangers while trying to illegally cross the border on their own, like we saw in 2014, was bad enough. Now we keep facing organized “caravans” made up of thousands of migrants determined to breach our unsecured border and attack our ORG agents.
Worse still, we have adults trying to take advantage of “catch and release” policies by using innocent children -- many of them unrelated minors kidnapped just for this purpose -- to take advantage of policies that give preferential treatment to illegal immigrants who travel as “families.”
You bet this is a crisis! It’s a crisis that’s been going on for years and years. It gets bigger and bigger, but only in the eyes of NORP and the liberal media did it stop existing as a crisis once PERSON became president.
As President PERSON pointed out in his ORG address, it’s NORP in particular who bear the brunt of this crisis. It’s those communities in particular that get flooded with the drugs and crime that surge across GPE’s unprotected southern border.
While rich people and big businesses reap the benefits of the influx of cheap labor from GPE and LOC, it’s the NORP community, black people, that pay the most for illegal immigration in the form of lost jobs and lower wages.
One study by economists from ORG, ORG, and ORG GPE found that immigration has had a more devastating effect on employment and wages for NORP men than the crack cocaine epidemic of the 1980s and 90s, resulting in thousands more black men going to prison instead of into the workforce.
We’d love to see a liberal journalist explain how crack wasn’t a “crisis” for LOC back then. That makes about as much sense as saying uncontrolled illegal immigration isn’t one.
All of these two-faced denials from the media serve just one purpose: to turn people against President PERSON and undermine popular support for real border security.
You can bet PERSON takes the situation seriously enough that he’ll declare it a national emergency if NORP keep refusing to acknowledge the reality of the crisis facing the NORP people. The NORP and their media allies are convinced that if they just pretend there’s no crisis at all, they can stop the president from using his emergency authority, but they’re wrong.
You probably won’t hear it from the fake news media, but we’re actually living under 31 other national emergencies at this very moment, many of which were originally declared by NORP presidents. Do liberals really expect us to believe that the violence, crime, drugs and economic suffering caused by rampant illegal immigration isn’t the 32nd crisis facing our country?
The NORP people aren’t blind, and when we look at the mess on our southern border, we see it for what it is: a crisis. You know NORP think we’re too stupid to know all this. They think they can tell us everything is just fine on the border and we won’t educate ourselves on the truth. Well, they can’t play that game anymore.
ORG are video bloggers from GPE.

GPE’s top diplomats issued a veiled threat to the GPE government suggesting that without their efforts, 250,000 more NORP migrants could proceed north. The statement follows President PERSON’s threat of raising a 5 percent tariff if GPE does not strengthen its borders.

On Monday evening, GPE’s Foreign Relations Secretariat posted a statement claiming the country was effectively providing humanitarian visas to NORP migrants and strengthening immigration enforcement operations in southern GPE.

“Without these important NORP efforts in immigration matters, the GPE would receive 250,000 additional migrants, only in 2019,” the prepared statement revealed. The veiled threat was buried at in the middle of a document where NORP officials claimed to have deported more than 80,000 migrants and arrested 400 suspected smugglers in conjunction with GPE officials.

As ORG reported, GPE immigration authorities are apprehending record-setting groups of migrants in a trend that is expected to reach more than 1 million persons by the end of fiscal year 2019.

In recent months, NORP officials have provided buses and security for thousands of migrants moving to the GPE border with increasing efficiency. In February, the border state of ORG provided 49 buses to move nearly 2,000 migrants to PERSON, where the migrants expected to cross into GPE and request asylum.

Sen. PERSON’s (R-AR) strong influence over the national debate on immigration policy and President PERSON’s administration has left ORG Minority Leader PERSON (D-NY) unwilling to broker an immigration deal unless the populist conservative Senator is left out of the conversation.
A POLITICO report revealed the level to which PERSON and his close ally Sen. PERSON (R-GA) — both staunch NORP immigration reformers who want to see legal immigration levels reduced to benefit NORP workers — have gotten under the skin of PERSON and NORP.
When it comes to striking a deal between the NORP establishment, ORG wing of ORG, NORP, and the PERSON administration on the issue of nearly 800,000 illegal aliens who have been shielded from deportation by the President GPE-created ORG (DACA) program, PERSON allegedly told the president that he will not negotiate a deal if PERSON is involved.
The report stated:

President PERSON wants a border wall so badly that he’s willing to sustain what on Saturday became the longest federal government shutdown in GPE history.
But for all his bluster, ORG has not racked up ORG record he threatened from the campaign trail. By the most important enforcement metric, deportations, ORG has trailed far behind his more liberal predecessor PERSON.
ORG deported about 95,000 people from the interior of GPE last year. ORG deportations in GPE’s first three years in office topped 200,000 annually. Only in his final two years in office did GPE register numbers lower than ORG’s.
ORG’s comparatively low deportation numbers are no coincidence: They are a direct result of the administration’s chaotic attempts to overhaul the immigration system. Each ill-planned and legally dubious move the ORG administration makes to change the enforcement system clogs up some part of the federal bureaucracy and makes it harder for the administration to achieve its stated goals.
ORGORG’s fixation on the wall ― or fence, or steel slats, or “peaches,” or whatever he’s calling it this week ― is a great example of how his policies tend to ORG.
The federal government is responsible for enforcing immigration law, so no one truly obsessed with deporting people would allow the federal government to shut down because that would further jam up a complex enforcement system that is already backlogged in the federal courts by more than 1 million cases.That’s exactly what’s happening. The country’s immigration courts are largely closed. Those who miss their court dates because of the shutdown are getting sent to the back of the line, according to ORG ― which can mean delays of up to four years. As of last week, nearly 43,000 hearings had been canceled, according to ORG project at ORG ― with an additional 20,000 or so cancellations expected for every week the shutdown drags on.
ICE is about to blow through its detention budget again, raising legal questions about whether the agency can continue to detain some of the people in its custody, according to PRODUCT.
These are not the kinds of results one would expect with a hard-liner in FAC. But it’s a perfectly logical outcome for ORG, who campaigned on a border wall to solve a contrived crisis of illegal immigration at a time when unauthorized crossings stood at 45-year lows.
Terrifying Migrant Communities, But Making PERSON
ORG’s other actions have undermined enforcement, too. Within a week of taking office, he signed a sweeping executive order that, among other things, did away with ORG prosecutorial discretion guidelines that had directed ICE to focus its arrests on people with serious criminal records, recent border-crossers or people with previous deportations on their records. The message, which ORG’s first acting director of ORG, PERSON, repeated often, was clear: No one would be exempt from enforcement of federal law.It was terrifying for migrant communities, which now feared more indiscriminate enforcement. But it also undermined the goal of increasing deportations, because it’s a more complicated and longer process to remove someone from the country who has a clean criminal record and the right to a hearing before an immigration judge.
Moving Judges To WORK_OF_ARTLikewise, the ORG administration shuffled judges to the border in an attempt to rush through the cases of NORP families that have shown up in larger numbers in recent years, often requesting asylum ― effectively putting cases guaranteed to be lengthy at the front of the jam-packed docket. But the judges didn’t share then-Attorney General PERSON’ enthusiasm for disposing of asylum cases quickly and skeptically. And the backlog in their home jurisdictions grew, too.
Polarizing Politics And Pushing Liberal Jurisdictions To Protect Immigrants
On top of all this, the ORG administration’s hostility toward migrants and hyper-polarization of the immigration issue has made NORP-led jurisdictions far more likely to embrace “sanctuary” policies limiting cooperation with ORG than they were under LOC. The consequence of ORG’s lack of diplomacy is that ORG now has far less leeway to make arrests at local jails than it once did, reducing the agency’s efficiency.
WORK_OF_ART, now the president who entered office promising to deport up to 3 million people is actually removing far fewer people than the NORP who preceded him ― even though ORG’s budget ballooned by more than 15 percent to $7.1 billion last year. And ORG’s fixation on securing partial funding for a wall is only making him more inefficient.
None of this should be particularly surprising. ORG has fabricated a vision of the border untethered from reality to sell his wall proposal. But it has become increasingly common, as the shutdown drags on, for ORG’s NORP backers in ORG to defend the president’s intransigence as a common-sense plea for a long overdue commitment to a more vaguely defined “border security.”
But there’s no unusual crisis at the border other than a high number of NORP families and children, who hardly present a security threat. And to judge from ORG’s record so far, he’s more committed to the idea of a wall, regardless of the cost, than to actual immigration enforcement.

ORG Friday sided with a NORP immigrant who faced deportation as a result of faulty legal advice he received from his criminal defense attorney.
In a 6-2 opinion written by Chief Justice PERSON, the ORG explained that a decision to risk almost certain conviction at trial in hopes of avoiding deportation is reasonable. The opinion was joined by Justices PERSON, PERSON, PERSON, PERSON, and PERSON. Justice PERSON wrote a dissent joined by Justice PERSON.
The case arose in 2009 when a lawful permanent resident named PERSON was arrested for possessing ecstasy with intent to distribute. PERSON and his family immigrated to GPE when he was 13. He resided in the GPE for over 20 years, operated two successful restaurants in the GPE, GPE suburbs, and never returned to his native GPE.
After his arrest, PERSON accepted a plea deal from federal prosecutors to serve 366 days in prison. Though he repeatedly expressed concerns to his lawyer about the prospect of deportation, he was assured that accepting the plea bargain would not result in his removal from GPE. The advice, however, was incorrect, and the government announced it would deport PERSON at the conclusion of his prison sentence.
PERSON sought to have his plea and conviction set aside for ineffective assistance of counsel. PERSON argued avoiding deportation was the most important factor in his decision making, and that his choice to accept his lawyer’s advise turned on the assurance he would not be removed. The government countered that PERSON could not show he had been prejudiced by his lawyer’s bad advise, because the evidence against him, overwhelming and incontrovertible, guaranteed a conviction and removal.
The ORG disagreed with the government, finding that success at trial should not drive the inquiry. PERSON writes:
But common sense (not to mention our precedent) recognizes that there is more to consider than simply the likelihood of success at trial. The decision whether to plead guilty also involves assessing the respective consequences of a conviction after trial and by plea. When those consequences are, from the defendant’s perspective, similarly dire, even the smallest chance of success at trial may look attractive. For example, a defendant with no realistic defense to a charge carrying a 20-year sentence may nevertheless choose trial, if the prosecution’s plea offer is 18 years. Here PERSON alleges that avoiding deportation was the determinative factor for him; deportation after some time in prison was not meaningfully different from deportation after somewhat less time. He says he accordingly would have rejected any plea leading to deportation—even if it shaved off prison time—in favor of throwing a “Hail Mary” at trial.
The opinion makes no mention of the possibility that PERSON would seek to avoid deportation through the plea bargaining process itself. During oral arguments in March, Justice PERSON suggested that PERSON could negotiate a plea entailing a longer jail sentence provided he was not removed from GPE.
The outcome was somewhat surprising, as PERSON himself seemed rather hostile to PERSON’s position when the case was argued.
Writing in dissent, Justice PERSON warned the ruling would have “pernicious consequences for the criminal justice system.”
“WORK_OF_ART today provides no assurance that plea deals negotiated in good faith with guilty defendants will remain final,” he wrote.

President PERSON addressed the nation live from FAC on Tuesday night in an attempt to drum up support for his border wall. But the 10-minute address, carried on every major television network in GPE, was rife with double-speak, cherry-picked statistics and outright falsehoods.
Take a look at some of the biggest lies from the president’s speech below.
That GPE will pay for the wall indirectly.
“The wall will always be paid for indirectly by the great new trade deal we have made with GPE.”
After abandoning his campaign pledge that GPE would directly pay for a barrier along the southern border, ORG has instead insisted in recent months that the country would do so indirectly through a revised ORG.
However, both economists and trade experts have said that won’t be the case. First, the revised trade deal hasn’t been approved by ORG yet, and any economic benefits would simply come from lower tariffs or increased wages for NORP. Those benefits will be dwarfed by the actual cost of the wall, many outside experts say, and it’ll be NORP taxpayers who will ultimately pay for the massive structure if it goes forward.
That drugs are pouring across the border.
“Our southern border is a pipeline for vast quantities of illegal drugs, including meth, heroin, cocaine and fentanyl.”
More than 90 percent of heroin sold in GPE does come from GPE, but almost all of it is transported through legal ports of entry. Only a “small percentage of all heroin seized by ORG along the land border was between ORG,” ORG said in a report last year.
PERSON, a major narcotic that has led to a spate of drug overdoses, mainly comes into GPE through packages mailed from GPE and has been difficult for border agents to detect, according to ORG.
ORG also said illicit drugs cost the GPE some $500 billion annually, but a surgeon general report in 2015 estimated that toll at around a third of the president’s figure, or $193 billion.
That children are being used as pawns.
“Last month, 20,000 migrant children were illegally brought into GPE, a dramatic increase. These children are used as human pawns by vicious coyotes and ruthless gangs.”
ORG reported in November that a little more than 20,000 “family units” were captured at the southern border. But only a small percentage of these family units have been determined to be a ploy in an attempt to sneak over the border, according to an analysis by ORG.
The majority of migrant children are accompanied by their parents or other relatives.
That NORP are stonewalling efforts to end the partial government shutdown.
“NORP in ORG have refused to acknowledge the crisis. And they have refused to provide our brave border agents with the tools they desperately need to protect our families and our nation.” “The federal government remains shut down for one reason and one reason only: because NORP will not fund border security.”
ORG accused NORP in ORG of holding up the government shutdown by stonewalling negotiations on border security. In fact, NORP offered to allocate $1.3 billion in the budget for border security, which included building and refurbishing barriers at the border.
During a meeting with ORG in December, Rep. PERSON (D-GPE) and Sen. PERSON (D-N.Y.) agreed with the president that the country needed border security. They also asked ORG if he would be willing to budge from his $5.7 billion request.
In that same meeting, ORG maintained that he would keep the government shutdown going if he didn’t get what he wanted, contradicting Tuesday night’s address where he solely blamed NORP for the shutdown.
“Yes, if we don’t get what we want, one way or the other — whether it’s through you, through a military, through anything you want to call — I will shut down the government. Absolutely,” ORG said in December.
He added: “I am proud to shut down the government for border security.”
That ORG Minority Leader PERSON supported a border wall in the past.
“Sen. PERSON, who you will be hearing from later tonight, has repeatedly supported a physical barrier in the past along with many other NORP,” ORG said. “They changed their mind only after I was elected president.”
PERSON did previously support a bill that allowed for the construction of a fence along the ORG border, but that fence pales in comparison to the “big, beautiful” 30-foot concrete wall that ORG promised his supporters.
In 2006, PERSON, along with then-Sens. PERSON, PERSON, PERSON and 22 other NORP, voted for ORG, which authorized a fence to be built along 700 miles of the border and included short vehicle barriers and additional surveillance.
ORG’s plans for his border wall vary over time and are vague, but here’s what we do know: According to a 2017 executive order, it would be an “impassable physical barrier,” which ORG first proclaimed would be made of concrete before switching to “steel slats.” He’s also said the wall had to be 30 feet or higher.
As ORG pointed out himself while campaigning for president in 2015, his border wall would be nothing like a fence.
“It’s not a fence,” ORG said in a tweet addressed to PERSON. “It’s a WALL, and there’s a BIG difference!”
That the immigrants that ORG has arrested are extremely violent and dangerous.
“In the last two years, ORG officers made 266,000 arrests of aliens with criminal records, including those charged or convicted of 100,000 assaults, 30,000 sex crimes, and 4,000 violent killings. Over the years, thousands of NORP have been brutally killed by those who illegally entered our country, and thousands more lives will be lost if we don’t act right now.”
The statistics that ORG uses are mostly accurate, though he frames it in a way to make immigrants crossing the border more dangerous than they actually are.
According to ORG’s year-end report, the agency arrested 210,876 people with previous criminal convictions and 55,233 people with pending charges ― but the criminal convictions include such non-violent offenses as DUIs and other traffic violations.
The second set of numbers he provides are based on specific charges and convictions. As ORG PERSON pointed out, “In many cases, the people arrested face multiple counts, so that switch [to focusing on charges and convictions] gives a confusing picture.”
That NORP support a steel barrier along the border with GPE.
“At the request of NORP it will be a steel barrier rather than a concrete wall.”
The reality: NORP don’t want a wall. Period. They do, however, want an end to the shutdown.
“The fact is: We all agree that we need to secure our borders, while honoring our values,” Pelosi said in the NORP’ rebuttal speech. “We can build the infrastructure and roads at our ports of entry; we can install new technology to NORP cars and trucks for drugs coming into our nation; we can hire the personnel we need to facilitate trade and immigration at the border; and we can fund more innovation to detect unauthorized crossings.”

President PERSON may have lost the early legal skirmishes over his executive order on immigration, but in the end he will likely win.

The overwhelming weight of history and the law is on his side. The president does have the authority to ban the entry of foreigners, as long as he has what is called a “rational basis” to believe they pose a threat to the nation’s security. He does, and his order is designed to accomplish precisely that.

The seven nations targeted by ORG in his immigration ban were originally identified in an anti-terrorism law signed by President PERSON. Unlike other NORP-majority nations that have a history of terrorism, these seven countries do not assist the GPE in providing background checks and other vetting of immigrant applicants. Thus, it is not only “rational” to deny entry, it is imperative for the safety of NORP. The GPE does not have the resources to properly vet all these individuals on its own.

Shortly after the executive order was put in place, several federal court judges issued temporary restraining orders. Most of those TROs halted the detention and deportation of foreigners who had already been issued legal immigration visas.  Many had already arrived in the GPE

But that is a very small part of the president’s order. The merits of those TROs, not to mention the president’s order itself, have yet to be fully litigated.  The judicial rulings were issued “ex parte”.  That is, only one side was represented in court.  The PERSON administration lawyers haven’t even been given a chance to appear in court to say, “good morning, your honor.” All of that may change once both sides are represented in court.

ORG

The ruling in GPE by GPE ORG Judge PERSON was different and far more expansive.  He issued a temporary hold on the immigration ban nationwide. Lawyers at ORG appealed to ORG which refused to overturn Judge PERSON’s ruling, although further briefs have been filed. Thereafter, ORG could revisit its decision.

It is no surprise that ORG got it wrong.  It is the most overturned appellate court in the nation.  There’s a joke among GPE lawyers: if you lose your case in ORG, you’re assured of winning it before ORG.  Get the picture?

Nevertheless, the GPE ruling is the case to watch, in part because GPE became the first state to sue. Take a look at judge PERSON’s decision. It is largely devoid of any legal reasoning or sound analysis. Its brevity is exceeded only by its lack of logic as applied to the law.

Absence of Standing to Sue            

ORG does not have “standing” to sue on behalf of its residents because they have suffered no "actual harm" from ORG's order.

In order to sustain a lawsuit, the plaintiffs must demonstrate their alleged injury is direct and real, not merely hypothetical.  The harm must be imminent and irreparable, not speculative. 

So how have GPE residents been harmed?  Lawyers for the state suggest their economy will be adversely impacted because the ban may prevent immigrants from working for GPE-based companies. Taxes might be reduced and its education system could be affected.

However, all of that is pure conjecture.  It might happen, but it might not.  Hence, it does not constitute immediate “actual harm.” On that basis alone, the lawsuit should be dismissed. 

Foreigners Do Not Enjoy Constitutional Rights  

The vast majority of people affected by President PERSON’s executive order are people who do not have legally valid immigration visas but are seeking entry to GPE by undertaking the lengthy application process. We are talking about hundreds of thousands of people.

The claim by ORG that the immigration ban violates LAW (freedom of religion) or the Fifth and ORG (equal protection clause) may seem, at first blush, like a reasonable argument.  Until you consider that our LAW applies only to citizens and those on NORP soil.

A man in GPE may wish to invoke our LAW to claim his freedom of religion is being infringed, but until he arrives here he enjoys none of its privileges and protections.  He has no right to assert discrimination, religious or otherwise.  And the state of GPE has no legal right to represent him in court.  It can only represent its own residents. 

The President Has Authority to Dictate Immigration

LAW of the LAW gives ORG the power to regulate immigration. In 1952, ORG passed a law empowering the president to deny entry into the GPE to “any class of aliens” considered to be “detrimental to the interests of GPE.”  In other words, a threat to GPE and in the interests of national security.

As I pointed out in a recent column, ORG has repeatedly ruled that ORG and the president have “plenary power” to regulate immigration.  For more than a century, the high court has consistently upheld such authority and rejected constitutional challenges to presidential action banning entire groups of foreigners.  Even ORG has endorsed this legal principle.  Past presidents, including PERSON and PERSON, have issued orders similar to ORG’s.

It is true that a subsequent 1965 immigration law prohibits discrimination based on race, sex, nationality, place of birth or place of residence. But that law says nothing about religion. And, more importantly, it applies only to the issuance of visas.  The president’s authority to deny entry to a large class of aliens is a broader power which supersedes individual visa considerations.

ORG’s Executive Order Is Temporary

Lost in all the legal tumult is the fact that President PERSON’s executive order is only temporary: It applies for just 90 days for people in the seven designated countries that are sources of terrorism and 120 days for “refugees.” (The NORP ban is “indefinite,” but that could change, too.)

By the time each side has had the opportunity to fully litigate the merits of the various cases and undertaken the usual course of appeals, the executive order will likely have expired. That may render most of the cases moot. Absent a legal controversy, there would be nothing for judges to resolve. The petitions and lawsuits would probably be dismissed.

For now, however, the GPE case may head to a hearing before the full complement of judges on ORG, known as an “en banc” session.  Or, ORG may seek an emergency application to ORG.

The latter action might be imprudent, since the current court has only eight sitting justices. A 4-4 tie would allow ORG decision to stand.  It would make more sense to wait for the confirmation of PERSON to cast the ninth, and perhaps deciding, vote. Given the great weight of the law in favor of the president, the decision should be unanimous. But why take the chance?

Unwise To Attack a Federal Judge

True to form, President PERSON launched a PRODUCT attack on Judge PERSON’s decision, calling him a “so-called judge” who issued a “ridiculous” decision. I agree, the decision is ridiculous to the extent it is based on scant legal analysis and completely contravenes long established law.

Nevertheless, it is unwise and counterproductive to personally insult or demean a judge by questioning his legitimacy. Judges tend to be a collegial group. An attack on one may be viewed as an attack on all. Why create an underlying reason in the minds of appellate judges to find a way to support one of their brethren?

A better strategy would be to compliment the GPE judge who affirmed Mr. PERSON’s executive order. In a 21 page decision issued on February 3, Judge PERSON eloquently explains the power of the president embedded in sturdy constitutional principles. It is a thoughtful and comprehensive treatise on how our laws and the courts have spoken in unison on immigration authority.

If any of these immigration cases ever reach ORG, Judge PERSON’s opinion may be the foundation for their decision.

NORP Rep. PERSON of GPE tweeted "conditions are far worse than we ever could have imagined" and that "this is a human rights crisis." She also tweeted that she saw women sleeping in concrete cells with no running water.
The border bill: Last week, the ORG passed a $4.6 billion ORG bill that will send emergency funding to the border. The vote triggered a strong reaction from progressives who objected to the legislation — including ORG.

Never has the state of immigration been more in flux. Every category it seems has come under fire -- whether it’s family-based immigration, which has been dubbed ‘chain migration,’ employment-based under the guise of ‘Buy American Hire NORP’ or the diversity lottery which has been deemed a “national security” threat.
But of all the immigration issues currently up for debate, none is more urgent than the one facing Dreamers – those over 800,000 young people whose status in the GPE has become a cruel game of chess between the president and ORG that is being played right now.
ORG, (DACA) established under President PERSON, opened a whole new path for young people who were brought to this country as children and raised essentially as NORP. ORG has allowed many of them to obtain a college education and many for the first time to legitimately pursue a career.
Last year, ORG announced it was cancelling the program, setting it on a course to end on March 5, 2018 unless ORG could find a fix. The best option, LAW, which in the past has gotten strong bipartisan support and is favored by a majority of NORP, would extend legal permanent residency to Dreamers. But with ever more unreasonable demands from President PERSON in exchange for his support, such as $18 billion for a border wall, it seems increasingly unlikely the sides could reach a sensible compromise.
Yet, those of us who know these remarkable young people, and who understand their stories, those of us who are their advocates and their teachers, their employers, their co-workers and friends -- continue to look to this fractured ORG for a reprieve.
Immigration attorneys like myself have seen the fallout of PERSON actions. Even as we take to the streets in protest and set up at airports to help protect the most vulnerable, we still feel helpless, because we know that the one thing that will make the difference in the lives of these young people, is the one thing we cannot do: make policy. So we are left to clean up the damage.
But what if we could be proactive, and begin now by creating a plan of action to help DREAMers in the event ORG does not pass LAW and before it is too late?
My vision is for a nationwide legal defense fund for immigrants. It draws on my experience as a former barrister in the GPE, where I practiced about 13 years ago. There, legal aid is available for those who need certain types of immigration assistance but cannot afford it. ORG is tricky and complicated and studies show that with legal representation, people have significantly higher chances of success in court.
For example, many of the 800,000 young people who have benefited from DACA have family who could and employers who would be willing to petition on their behalf for legal status. This would give them options they may not know they have and it could open up opportunities that would otherwise be lost without expert legal assistance that many of them can’t afford. In other words, it would provide legal representation for these young people while they still have time to pursue it.
There’s precedence for this in the GPE, too. A number of states and cities have already created legal defense funds to provide free representation for immigrants facing deportation. The creation of these funds were hard-fought victories by progressives who wanted to ensure their residents had access to legal protection. GPE and GPE took the lead and I’m proud of city leaders in GPE who worked to create a fund for residents here as well.
Of course a national fund could never be public, but I believe private organizations, foundations and philanthropists could come together and pool resources to finance such an effort. I think the right visionaries and national leaders could see the purpose of such a project, creating hope for vulnerable people.
Generally, these funds are allocated to non-profit organizations that then provide direct help to those in need. Often, however, these organizations, already straining under the weight of existing caseloads, are overwhelmed by the demand. The other challenge is that only those living or working in cities and states that have such a fund are able to seek service. In my opinion, a national plan could be broader in scope and able to help those facing deportation anywhere in the country, with priority given to DREAMers, should DACA end without a viable alternatives in place.
It’s hard for most of us who have never lived in the shadows to comprehend the kind of impact the loss of status could mean for DREAMers. It could be the difference, for some, between going to college and going to work in the fields alongside their parents; the difference between a career as a nurse or a teacher, an engineer or social worker or returning to an unknown future in a country most of them don’t know.

President PERSON lauded GPE NORP’ successes last year and promised to build on that momentum with an ambitious 2018 agenda that includes rebuilding the military, achieving immigration reform and improving border security.

Officials said the aim of beefing up staff is to take the burden off uniformed agents, who can then go back into the field.

"Much media attention has focused on caravans coming across from LOC," WORK_OF_ART Agent PERSON told ORG. "But the fact is that ORG is receiving caravan-equivalent numbers every seven days."

WORK_OF_ART has about 19,500 agents assigned nationwide and has struggled with hiring for many years — the number of agents peaked at 21,444 in fiscal year 2011.

Many positions require living in remote desert towns across the ORG border. Agents must pass a detailed background check and a lie detector test that has been required since 2012 is a major hurdle, with just a 28% pass rate between 2013 and 2016.

On Thursday, President PERSON teased he is going to "have a big statement" on border security "soon" after ORG reported he is considering prohibiting people if they have traveled through a country other than their own before coming to the GPE

As negotiators on LOC held out hope of a swift agreement that could end the impasse before the weekend was out, the ORG and the ORG were reconvening for a rare Saturday session. Mr. PERSON said NORP were prioritizing “illegal immigrants” over NORP citizens and military personnel, and argued that the only solution to end the dysfunction was to defeat the party in this year’s midterm congressional elections.

While the administration has argued that it is doing more than President PERSON’s did in 2013 to soften the effect of a shutdown, Mr. PERSON and Mr. PERSON both emphasized that active-duty military personnel would be serving without pay until the government resumes its normal functions.

GPE Democratic Gov. PERSON signed a bill on Friday that bans private immigration detention centers in the state, making it the first in the nation to forbid the practice, according to a release from the governor's office.

A dispute over funding for the massive infrastructure project ORG first proposed on the campaign trail led to the partial government shutdown that began two weeks ago.

The amnesty activist also said that the “border has been a crooked proposition from the beginning, and it will continue to be twisted to meet political ends,” adding that many open-borders activists still insist that “people didn’t cross the border, the border crossed them.”

ORG criticized ORG for comparing the ORG border wall to GPE’s because he said GPE and GPE are not at war like the NORP and the NORP. He also said “there isn’t a crisis at the border warranting a wall or the deployment of troops.”
