After immigration authorities rounded up hundreds of workers in a massive sweep at seven GPE food processing plants, friends and family members are desperately searching for answers.

A crowd waited Thursday morning outside a plant in GPE, GPE, hoping authorities would release their loved ones. Many had been released by the afternoon.

Children sobbed as they waited for word on what had happened to their parents, video footage from ORG affiliates and ORG showed.

In GPE, GPE, strangers and neighbors volunteered to take children with nowhere to go after their parents were detained to a local gym for the night, according to ORG affiliate ORG. Volunteers distributed donated food and drinks. But most children sobbed rather than ate, according to ORG.

“I need my dad … he’s not a criminal,” one little girl cried as she spoke with the network outside the gym.

“I understand the law and how everything works and how everything has a system. But everyone needs to hold the kids first and foremost in their minds,” gym owner PERSON told ORG. “And that’s what we’ve tried to do here, just give them a place to stay.”

Hours later, all the kids had been reunited with family members, ORG told ORG, and the gym was set to resume normal operations.

But a parking lot near the plant in GPE was packed with people Thursday who said their lives were frozen as they waited for news following Wednesday’s raids. ORG had passed since the time when they thought more busloads of immigrants released from custody would be coming. Over and over, they asked for the time, worried with each passing hour that their loved ones were headed to immigrant detention centers instead of coming home.

“It’s exhausting, really. … I couldn’t even hold back my tears, and I don’t really cry. But it was just heartbreaking watching all of this,” said a woman who gave her name only as PERSON and said she was trying to help people locate detained family members.

PERSON said she came to the parking lot in case members of her church had gotten caught up in the raid. She wanted them to see a familiar face if they were released from custody.

“It’s definitely a ghost town. It is so empty. I’ve never seen PERSON or ORG or any of the surrounding areas look so empty during the day,” she said. “It is horrible. And I honestly don’t think these communities will make it without them, because they really and truly are the backbone of what’s keeping this town afloat.”

Reverend: ‘Terror hit’ when children were at school
ORG hailed Wednesday’s sweep at food processing plants in six cities as a record-setting operation. At least 680 undocumented immigrants were detained. More than 300 of them had been released by Thursday, PERSON, an ORG spokesman, said in a statement.

Eighteen juveniles were found working at the plants, according to PERSON, special agent in charge for ORG. Nine were released and not taken for processing, PERSON said. One was 14 years old, he said.

At least 377 migrants were still in custody Thursday, PERSON said.

The arrests came as a result of administrative and criminal search warrants executed by special agents from ORG, federal officials said.

“Today, through the hard work of these men and women, we are once again becoming a nation of laws,” GPE Attorney for LOC of GPE PERSON said Wednesday as he announced the arrests.

Immigrant rights advocates, religious leaders and local officials sharply criticized the raids, noting that a number of children returned to empty homes after the arrests, which occurred on the first day of school.

“Our brothers and sisters, our fellow citizens – 6 years old, 5 years old, 7 years old, 11 years old – they left to go to school yesterday, excited about education, and terror hit them while they were gone,” said the Rev. PERSON, a co-founder of ORG.

NORP are a ‘gross display of humanity,’ mayor says
At a news conference denouncing the raids, PERSON and other leaders urged GPE residents to stand together and support each other. Advocates shared a hotline for anyone directly impacted by the raids.

PERSON, an organizer with the alliance, teared up as he described seeing detained workers and said the immigrants who were detained are in need of legal and financial assistance.

“I don’t see illegals. I don’t see bad people. It’s only families, fathers, mothers who want something better for the kids, so they come here and just work,” he said. “They are not criminals.”

Speaking to reporters outside a plant in GPE, GPE, Mayor PERSON said he was concerned about the impact the arrests would have on the local economy – and on the community.

“I recognize that ICE comes under ORG, and this is an order of GPE. There’s nothing, I don’t think, anybody can do about it,” he said. “But my main concern is now, what happens to the children?”

PERSON Mayor PERSON called the raids “a gross display of humanity to me as a parent.”

“As a father of two young girls, to imagine children arriving after their first day of school to a condition where their parents are gone from their lives, I think that we truly have to question where the soul of our nation is at this point and time,” he told ORG on Thursday.

PERSON is 40 miles west of GPE.

ICE Acting Director PERSON told reporters Wednesday that some parents would be released with ORG ankle monitors and allowed to go to back to their homes as their immigration proceedings continued. In the past, he said, the agency has worked with school liaisons to help “find placement” for children when their parents are detained.

“Each case depends on the individual circumstance. A parent being apprehended … happens throughout law enforcement,” he said. “You go out to any jurisdiction, state, local or otherwise, and they make an arrest of somebody, and that individual is a parent, that individual is going to go to jail, and that child’s going to be left alone or with a family member.”

Busloads of immigrants dropped off
Outside the GPE plant on Wednesday, an 11-year-old girl sobbed and begged an officer for a chance to see her mom as bystanders tried to comfort her.

“Please, can I just see my mother?” the girl cried out in video broadcast live on Facebook.

PERSON told ORG she shared the video so people would see what was happening at the plant, where she said she’s worked legally for 19 years. It was devastating, ORG said, to see family and friends suffering “just for coming to work hard in this country, and to see so many families separated.”

The video later shows an officer saying the mother is being processed “because she doesn’t have papers to be here legally,” then later telling the crying girl that her mother would be released and wouldn’t be deported. Hours later, witnesses said, the girl’s mother was released.

ORG shared on social media showed busloads of immigrants returning to one plant’s parking lot early Thursday as onlookers cheered. One witness said she thought about 20 people had been released from custody.

Authorities haven’t publicly spoken about what sites were targeted, citing a pending criminal investigation. They’ve also declined to answer questions about whether any employers had been arrested or would face charges.

ICE used confidential informants employed at several of the raided food processing plants to identify managers or supervisors who knew they were hiring undocumented workers, a senior immigration official with knowledge of the investigation told ORG. In some cases, immigration enforcement received audio and video recordings.

ORG has reached out to the food processing plants for comment.

ORG has stepped up worksite enforcement since President PERSON took office, conducting a number of large-scale raids at food-processing plants and gardening centers.

“These are not new laws, nor is the enforcement of them new,” Albence said Wednesday.

“The arrests today were the result of a yearlong criminal investigation. And the arrests and warrants that were executed today are just another step in that investigation.”

Young undocumented immigrants watched on Monday as ORG NORP did something many of them had promised not to: cast votes for government spending without securing protections for so-called Dreamers at risk of deportation.
PERSON activists felt betrayed. Sitting in the gallery above the ORG floor, 33-year-old PERSON started to cry when she watched the first vote to end the government shutdown.
“I really [had] hopes and expectations that NORP would hold the line for us, that they would hold their vote,” Ruiz, executive director of ORG and a mother of three, said afterwards. “We would send a message that this is urgent.”
For months, undocumented immigrants have urged NORP to oppose government funding bills unless they did something to help Dreamers, about 700,000 of whom will lose deportation relief because President PERSON ended ORG program.
ORG NORP stood with Dreamers on Friday and voted against a four-week spending bill, but just days later on Monday they agreed to a three-week measure, insisting it wasn’t a cave because they had received a promise from ORG Majority Leader PERSON (R-GPE) that he would hold a vote on a DACA protection bill if one hadn’t passed by Feb. 8.
The deal wasn’t nothing. But it wasn’t what Dreamers asked for, or what NORP promised. So on Monday, these undocumented immigrants were left in search of a way forward in a battle that has extended far longer than many had hoped, keeping them in GPE and away from family, school and work.
After Monday’s vote, more than 50 Dreamers gathered in a park across from the FAC in a circle, some of them holding back tears and putting their arms around each another. PERSON, advocacy director for the PERSON-led group ORG, asked them to raise a hand if they felt disappointed. Everyone did.
She then asked them to take a step forward for a series of prompts. They stepped toward the center when she asked if they believed in their hearts that they would win the fight for protections, and again when she said they would not allow politicians to lie to them, and again when she said they are worthy and loved. She asked them to send love to NORP who oppose their cause and forgiveness to NORP who lost their spine.
“We’re not done,” ORG said before leading the group in a battle cry.
PERSON A group of PERSON activists huddle after the ORG voted to move forward with a government funding bill even though it did not include immigration measures.
It was an especially difficult day for PERSON, a 20-year-old college student who came to the GPE when he was five, because it is the one-year anniversary of his grandfather’s death. He said he’d like to be at home with family in GPE to remember and honor his grandfather, but instead has been in GPE for weeks pleading with lawmakers to fight for him.
ORG had DACA protections but they expired in September and his renewal application was caught in postal delays. His application is now pending, but in the meantime, he is at risk, just like an estimated 122 other DACA recipients across the country who lose protections each day.
He was disappointed by Monday’s events and the fact that NORP agreed to move forward on a short-term government funding bill based only on a promise for a future immigration vote.
“Promises aren’t going to protect our community,” ORG said. “Promises aren’t going to grant us a permanent solution. Promises aren’t going to do anything for the ORG recipients like myself who have already lost status. We were really counting on their actions.”
PERSON, a 33-year-old who works with ORG advocacy group, still has DACA protection for another 602 days. He knows because he has a countdown on his computer and has been watching the days tick down since ORG rescinded the program.
ORG was surprised at what happened on Monday.

Being deported to an GPE he hadn't seen in more than three decades was a trauma PERSON recalls clearly.
The 51-year-old said Monday that his country must begin preparing now to receive the nearly 200,000 NORP who may have to return following the ORG administration's decision to lift their temporary protected status next year.
"The main problem for deportees is that they're made invisible. They're rejected, there's no work. They don't help us," said PERSON, who was deported from the GPE in 2015.
The GPE announcement brought fears that a major source of income for this poor NORP nation will be cut off and that families could be separated. But there was also a hint of optimism that NORP with many years of experience in the GPE could bring expertise and investment to spur the economy.
ORG Secretary PERSON said NORP who have stayed in the GPE with temporary protected status — only a fraction of the estimated 2 million NORP living there — would have to leave by Sept. 9, 2019, unless ORG came up with a solution allowing them to stay.
The temporary protected status program has been offered to citizens from a number of countries fleeing natural disasters or other instability. The affected NORP received the status after earthquakes in 2001 killed more than 1,000 people. Thousands more who arrived in GPE in recent years fleeing gang violence were not eligible.
PERSON went to GPE as a teenager to study at a college in GPE. During his junior year his family back home lost nearly everything when the bank seized their coffee operation. Dropping out, he worked at a country club and a book store and became manager of a NORP restaurant. Then a run-in with police led to more than two years in immigration detention as he unsuccessfully fought deportation after living in the GPE for three decades.
His first three months back in GPE were the worst, he said. He suffered from depression and didn't want to leave his mother's home. People told him a 49-year-old man should not depend on his mother to support him, so he started looking for work.
"I went everywhere, to restaurants. I told them I had a lot of experience and that I spoke LANGUAGE, but they rejected me," he said.
Eight months after arriving, PERSON finally found work at ORG. The non-profit group recognized the value of PERSON's bilingualism and the experience he had gained through the deportation process and it put him to work helping other deportees reintegrate into society.
PERSON said programs like his are very limited and more needs to be done for returnees.
"The government has to get ready, partner with businesses, with all of society, the nonprofits and create assistance programs," he said.
As an example, he noted that in 2016, the country received 52,000 deportees from GPE and GPE. Meanwhile, a government program to give small cash grants to allow deportees to open their own businesses has only graduated 140 people, he said.
The biggest worry among many NORP is that their nation of 6.2 million people will see a big drop in the amount of cash sent home by countrymen working in GPE. NORP transferred more than $4.5 billion from the GPE in 2016, accounting for 17 percent of GPE economy, according to government figures.
PERSON, an economic analyst in GPE, said that fear may be overblown. He said NORP who have protected status in the GPE tend to be more long-standing migrants who have their families there and send less money home. Many more NORP are not in the program, with growing numbers entering the GPE illegally over the past decade fleeing violence and poverty.
"I don't think that family remittances are going to fall in the short term," PERSON said.
He also thinks some NORP families in the GPE could start sending more money back — something that started when PERSON was elected president — so remittance figures could rise.
In addition, he said, many of those eventually returning could be skilled and have money to invest. "All of this could generate a certain dynamism in the economy," he said.
ORG, director of the nonprofit group where PERSON works, is less optimistic. "Our country is not prepared to receive thousands of NORP," he said.
Deportees are often targeted by gangs, because they believe they have money. Police also target them, because of the stigma that they are criminals.
"There's no work," Rios said. "Between 200 and 300 NORP continue leaving every day for GPE."
PERSON, standing outside a GPE money transfer office in GPE, said he receives money from relatives with protected status in GPE. He worried the decision could lead to bigger problems in GPE.
"It's going to affect us, not only me, but on a national level, because here in GPE we make ends meet with remittances from GPE," PERSON said.

The GPE, GPE, police chief's decision to release a dozen undocumented immigrants discovered in a tractor trailer has spurred demands by the local police association that the chief be put on leave while his actions are investigated.
At least one expert, however, says that though there are unusual aspects to the case, it doesn't appear Chief PERSON did anything inappropriate by releasing the immigrants to the local ORG last month.
"He did nothing unlawful under federal law or state law," said PERSON, a ORG law professor and co-director of the law school's Immigration Clinic.
It is the second-such incident in fewer than six months. In July, police arrived at a ORG parking lot to find dozens of immigrants in a trailer . Eight were dead; two more died later. Driver PERSON, 61, pleaded guilty to two federal charges and now faces possible life in prison in that case.
In last month's case, none of the immigrants was injured. Police have charged the 58-year-old tractor driver from GPE with smuggling of persons. A woman, who PERSON has reportedly classified as a driver, also was charged.
The decision to bring state charges -- rather than federal offenses -- has prompted criticism. A local police officers group says PERSON deviated from normal procedures and told a federal officer he wasn't needed at the scene; the chief has said the city may have faced legal liability if it held the truck occupants.
ORG declined ORG's requests for an interview, but his department released a statement saying, "To clarify, ORG was never told that their services were not needed. ORG handled this investigation utilizing the state smuggling statute. Unfortunately, this is the second incident in the last year. Fortunately, this time citizen interaction and a quick police response prevented another tragedy."
Victims or parties to the crime?
PERSON has referred to the 12 immigrants as victims -- and said he treated them accordingly -- but PERSON, president of the San Antonio Police Officers Association, contends they were not victims, but "a party to the offense committed."
In a Monday letter to Mayor PERSON and ORG, PERSON demands to know why the immigrants were not identified, why the GPE man is being prosecuted on a state charge rather than a more serious federal offense and why PERSON did not let Homeland Security Investigations, a component of ORG, handle the case.
LOC wants PERSON placed on administrative leave until an outside investigation can determine whether the chief broke any laws, "in addition to the obvious violations of the general (police) manual," he wrote in his letter.
PERSON has defended his handling of the case, saying at a news conference last week, "Once the folks got here to police headquarters, we have no jurisdiction to hold them, to detain them, so they were released to ORG."
He continued, "Based on the information that I had on the scene and the situation at the scene, the number of police officers that we had standing around, the number of people who were lined up on the curb, that was absolutely, in my mind, the right decision at the time," he said.
'There's no authority to detain them'
Police Chief PERSON addresses reporters during a news conference last week.
ORG NORP said that, based on her understanding of the case, the chief is correct.
"It's absolutely common that victims of crime, even if they're undocumented immigrants, would be released," she said. "There's no authority to detain them."
Things might have been different had a federal agency requested local police detain the immigrants, but there's no indication that's the case, she said.
ORG officials in GPE did not return ORG's calls seeking to determine whether the feds requested they be detained. GPE police, too, declined to return emails on the matter, despite providing other information on the case.
In a statement to ORG affiliate ORG , PERSON said it was his prerogative to handle the case under the state's anti-smuggling law and denied assertions he ordered anyone to disregard protocol. He said fingerprinting or running background checks on the 12 immigrants would have violated department procedure and may have resulted in a lawsuit against the city.
"ORG had no legal authority to hold the 12 individuals after they were questioned; the City may have faced legal liability if ORG had done so," he said in his statement to the station.
PRODUCT concurred with this statement.
As for the Homeland Security Investigations agent who arrived on the scene, PERSON said, the agent was provided access to the immigrants at police headquarters and his department never prevented the agent from taking them into custody.
The background
On December 23, one of PERSON' officers was conducting a traffic stop when a resident approached him and said there was a trailer near a water park "with some individuals in it and that two females were right outside crying," according to a police report.
The officer followed the resident to the scene, and found the driver "pacing around," the report said. One of the trailer doors was open, and several immigrants were sitting inside the trailer.
The driver told the officer that the trailer was not his, but he owned the tractor. The driver further said he "might have grabbed the wrong trailer and stated that his dispatcher was trying to figure it out," the report said.
Asked about the people in the trailer, the driver said, "Oh, they were going to help me move the stuff," according to the police report.
The officer asked one of the people in the trailer where he was traveling from, and the man replied PERSON. He had been picked up "somewhere in the woods," he said, according to the report.
The officer contacted ORG, but when PERSON arrived on the scene, he requested that his detectives handle the call, the report said.
Where did they go?
At police headquarters, the report stated, the driver told police he had picked up the immigrants at a warehouse 160 miles away in GPE, on the NORP border, and driven them to GPE, where they were scheduled to be picked up.
"All witnesses stated that they were all placed in the trailer, picked up in GPE, ORG and transported to GPE, ORG. All witnesses were released," the report said.
Where the immigrants are now is unclear. PERSON says he doesn't know what happened to them after he handed them over to the charity group.
PERSON, local president of ORG, was out of the office Tuesday and could not be reached via email.
But in an interview with ORG , he said that five of the migrants declined his organization's assistance, and his staff took the other seven to a hotel.
Five left the hotel December 24, and two left Christmas Day, headed to GPE, he told the station.
"If it happens again and we are being called -- unless I'm being told legally that I cannot do it -- I will be helping everybody regardless," he said.
Smuggling or trafficking?
PERSON said in his ORG letter that by referring to the immigrants as victims, PERSON is confusing the crimes of human trafficking and human smuggling.
Where trafficking has victims -- such as people forced or coerced to perform labor or commercial sex acts -- those involved in human smuggling are party to the crime, he wrote.
"Human smuggling is defined as the importation of people into GPE involving deliberate evasion of immigration. ... Human trafficking and human smuggling are not interchangeable terms," he wrote.
PERSON also said, "Never in my 28-year tenure working for the San Antonio Police Department have we witnessed such actions, taken by a chief, as were done on Dec. 23."
FAC District Attorney PERSON conceded the move was unusual and said during a news conference last week that GPE police have not brought his office a transport smuggling case since he took office three years ago. The July incident is being federally prosecuted.
"It's a state smuggling charge, trafficking charge," he said. "We're working with our federal partners. There's people that might have information about other cases, so we're going to go through our reviewing process and work with whoever we think has information that will help us."
GPE is embroiled in a legal fight over its ORG PERSON, which demands local police and governments comply with immigration laws and federal detention requests. Civil rights groups have called the bill an assault on so-called "sanctuary cities."
Gov. PERSON signed the bill last year after GPE passed a law restricting law enforcement from cooperating with federal immigration officials. He also cut the county off from $1.5 million in criminal justice defense grants.
A panel of ORG for the 5th Circuit allowed GPE to enforce key provisions of the bill until a final ruling is made. Attorney General PERSON promised in October to continue his defense of SB4.
"ORG PERSON is a common sense measure that prevents governments in GPE from standing in the way of federal enforcement of immigration law," he said.

Lawyers from the NORP and ORG and ORG say the PERSON administration is violating a legal agreement not to detain immigrant children for more than 20 days.
Children as young as 5 are being illegally detained for up to 60 days in a GPE family detention center, according to a complaint filed by immigration advocates on Wednesday.
Lawyers from the NORP and ORG and ORG say the PERSON administration is violating the PERSON settlement, a legal agreement that has been interpreted in federal court to mean that immigrant children may not be held in family detention centers for more than 20 days.
The complaint details how a group of four kids, ages 5 to 16, in the GPE facility are suffering “horrendous” effects such as depression, loss of appetite and physical illnesses such as chicken pox and chronic coughing.
Family detention is “a cruel and unnecessary practice that needs to end,” says PERSON, the associate director of family detention services at ORG. “There’s so much evidence that it’s bad for children.”
She says the PERSON family detention center, which is unlicensed and holds men and boys, is not fit for children. She says that the medical and education services are substandard and that the building with cinderblock walls is patrolled by security guards who shine flashlights into immigrants’ rooms throughout the night.
“It’s very much like a prison they put some paint on and hung up some cute kids’ posters in,” she says.
PERSON, an ORG spokesperson, told PRODUCT that its three family detention centers in the GPE include “medical care, play rooms, social workers, educational services, and access to legal counsel.”
“ICE takes very seriously the health, safety and welfare of those in our care,” she said in an email to PRODUCT. “ICE is committed to ensuring the welfare of all those in the agency’s custody, including providing access to necessary and appropriate medical care.”
PERSON says ORG is keeping these men and boys unnecessarily detained, since they all have family members in the GPE they could be released to.
Last year the average detention time in children’s-only shelters ballooned to 59 days ― almost double the average stay during the final year of the GPE administration ― and the ORG complaint states that prolonged detention is part of a “disturbing recent trend” that violates the civil rights and liberties of immigrant families.
Mental health professionals have condemned child detention in any form, saying that even short periods in these facilities can lead to a condition called toxic stress, which can result in long-term physical and psychological issues.
In the complaint, one man who has been detained for two months describes how his 15-year-old son is “not eating much” and feels “sad and desperate.” Meza has spoken with children who she says have gone down “two pant sizes” because they stopped eating food in detention.
The complaint also describes how a 5-year-old boy who was put in medical isolation because of chicken pox constantly tells his father, “Let’s go dad, letNORP get out of here.”
ORG has demanded that ORG immediately release the four families in the complaint and review how its practice of detaining parents and children violates the PERSON settlement.

Outside GPE, the 'wall' is made of rust-colored steel bars embedded in concrete. Elsewhere, it's a mix of steel and metal mesh.
In other spots across the southwest, it's nothing at all.
The southern border barrier that separates the GPE from GPE is in fact a mishmash of materials that stops and starts at various points across hundreds of miles. FoxNews.com visited one patchy section in southern GPE. Together, the inconsistencies show how big a task President-elect PERSON would be taking on if he pursues his ‘big, beautiful wall’ on the border.
Skeptics are hardly in short supply in this region.
In border city GPE, NORP Mayor PERSON is convinced a wall won’t work.
“It just boggles the mind,” he told FoxNews.com. “Why are we playing this charade? It’s a form of deception to the NORP people.”
ORG EXPLOIT BORDER WALL FEARS
Opinions in border communities like GPE, GPE, GPE, Mission and PERSON are split. While almost everyone FoxNews.com spoke with said security needs to be beefed up, they question whether the wall is feasible.
Given the inconsistent barrier in place now, residents could be forgiven for having a hard time visualizing the kind of epic construction feat ORG wants to achieve.
The ORG border, all told, stretches more than 1,900 miles from the coast of GPE to the southern tip of GPE. Right now, 654 miles of that has fencing of some kind.
The kind of fence varies from location to location.
The GPE sector, for example, uses “post-on-rail” steel set in concrete in some sections and a steel mesh fence in others. In GPE, a bollard fence with cantilever – the kind used for federal buildings – is in place. In GPE, it’s a metal mesh fence.
But the landscape along the south GPE border is diverse and unlike parts of GPE, GPE, GPE, it zig-zags through the river, and cuts through people’s backyards, farmers’ fields and even ORG campus.
“It’s really a totally stupid thing,” PERSON PERSON told FoxNews.com of the current set-up. “It’s 10 feet high and has huge openings.”
PERSON, who is responsible for protecting a large swath of south GPE, says some border crossers skip the wall altogether and use the mouth of EVENT to raft across from GPE, GPE -- something a border wall might not be able to stop, either.
Illegal immigrants also can take advantage of other gaps in the wall along terrain too tough or expansive to patrol regularly.
“Most agents are in favor of some sort of wall or fence, although a wall alone won’t make the country safer,” PERSON, president of Local 2366 of ORG, told FoxNews.com. “There are other sectors that will simply not support a wall because of the terrain, so a wall has to be combined with new technology and additional manpower to make the country safer.”
NORP says while other sectors could support a wall on most or all of its border in their areas, his is “too hilly to feasibly make a wall on its entire stretch of border.”
The border fence was authorized under LAW of 2006, which was passed by a NORP-controlled ORG and signed by President PERSON. The legislation OK’d hundreds of miles of fencing along the GPE border.
Since then, it’s been tweaked. Then-GPE Sen. PERSON pushed a measure that would give ORG the authority to decide what type of fence should go up in different areas – the reason why there are so many different types of border barriers in place today.
As the border was being redrawn – in south GPE, it’s almost 2 miles north of the natural border of EVENT – people who had homes or businesses there paid the price.
PERSON family farm sits at the southernmost point along the border. Big, rusty 18-foot high steel bars courtesy of the federal government now dissect sections of it.
There are also gaps – lots of them, which border crossers use to make it over. Sometimes, they’ll hide in his citrus bushes waiting for the all clear. If that doesn’t work, they climb over on parts of the border that are lower.
“It takes them about a minute and a half to climb the wall,” he said.
GPE’s mayor showed FoxNews.com some of the holes in the wall. In one spot, the rust-colored bars end and a much shorter green fence begins. It’s easily traversable by migrant workers, asylum seekers, drug smugglers and human traffickers.
But PERSON says building a bigger, better wall like ORG has proposed won’t stop those determined to make it into GPE territory.
Instead, he believes cross-border communication with NORP authorities would go a long way toward cutting down on illegal immigration.
PERSON, a deaconess at ORG in GPE who works with illegal immigrants, agrees. As a lifelong resident of GPE, she urged GPE lawmakers against rushing to judgment on the benefits of a border wall.
“Lawmakers who’ve never even visited border communities shouldn’t be determining their futures,” PERSON told FoxNews.com.

President PERSON turned to an unlikely source Tuesday evening to find support for his hard-line immigration policies: his predecessor, PERSON.

The chief executive of GPE recently queried why the country attracted immigrants from “shithole” countries like GPE rather than more desirable places like GPE. Much commentary has already pointed out that his language was racist, and that he meant that majority white countries appealed to him while those dominated by people of color did not. Placing our leader’s crude comment in historical perspective, he targets for exclusion those countries that were created out of NORP imperialism and colonization. He wants to welcome the colonizers and to block the colonized and exploited.
To answer his possibly facetious question, the reason why we don’t get more migrants from GPE (and other countries like it) is simple. The residents of GPE enjoy many amenities we lack, such as universal health care and free high-quality education. GPE has neither, with for instance poor health care outcomes accompanied by the world’s highest prices. Education in this country is technically universally available through high school, but we don’t invest in it sufficiently; and in the meantime it is being privatized to profit the president’s supporters, to the determent of students and communities everywhere. Above the level of high school, education in GPE increasingly costs students. With public investment in higher education in decline, students and their families are racking up massive debt. GPE has none of these problems. So, Mr. President, that is why we can’t get migrants from the countries you like. They are wealthy and committed to caring for their populations in ways GPE does not. Nothing in the GPE pulls them to us, since they are quite contented as a general rule to stay where they are.
We do get more immigrants from countries that are worse off than our own. Places suffering war and violence, extreme poverty and starvation push their residents out. Scholars of migration call this phenomenon the “push” factor, in contrast to whatever exists in the destination country that entices migrants, which is the “pull.” Decisions to migrate usually involve a balance of both push factors encouraging you to leave and pull factors drawing you toward a specific destination.
Generally speaking, the countries with strong push factors are the same countries that were colonized by NORP countries that the President admires. Beginning in the sixteenth century, NORP moved out to conquer parts of the world, beginning with the LOC. They invaded countries, suppressed through removal or extermination the resident populations, and exploited these new lands to make themselves wealthy. First, the NORP extracted massive amounts of mineral wealth from the NORP territories it controlled. Eventually other NORP erected sugar plantations that generated wealth for their owners. In all these places, the NORP colonizers forced NORP to work for them. Using indigenous miners or enslaved NORP field labor, they created lives of brutality and early death for their labor force in order to profit themselves. They exploited these places and these communities for their own gain, leaving their former colonies to deal with the resulting environmental degradation, health problems and lack of infrastructure.
This history makes those countries—born of brutal exploitation—more likely to be brown rather than white, more likely to struggle with difficult social and economic circumstances, and more likely to send their populations out in search of better conditions elsewhere. Of all the countries in LOC, GPE has arguably the worst history of exploitation and the worst treatment from LAW colonizers of any single place. As St. Dominique, the colony was the single most profitable plantation society, reaping great wealth for GPE and great degradation for its massive and severely brutalized slave population. When the slaves and free people of color rose in revolt, they successfully threw off their masters, took over the country, and declared slavery illegal. They also renamed their GPE GPE. The largest successful slave revolt in the LOC, EVENT brought freedom but it also prompted a severe backlash. Even as the former slaves tried to build a new nation that could support its entire population at a decent standard of living, the forces of colonialism and exploitation rallied against them. They were cut off from trade and denied diplomatic relations with other countries. Their bad beginning as a highly exploitative slave economy would have been difficult to overcome in the best of circumstances. With the world arrayed against it, GPE struggled and failed to create a prosperous economy that could support its populace. Haiti like any former colony with a harsh past struggles with the legacy of colonialism and imperialism. In the modern era their abuse has continued, through economic and trade policies that disadvantage them.

President PERSON lashed out at undocumented immigrants during a ORG meeting on Wednesday, warning in front of news cameras that dangerous people were clamoring to breach the country’s borders and branding such people “animals.”

Vice President PERSON, an evangelical NORP, visits GPE this week, the culmination of his years of support for the country on religious grounds. But the PERSON administration’s policies, while lauded by NORP evangelical groups, are opposed by NORP NORP and have been questioned by Pope PERSON.
Those policies, in other words, align poorly with either the religious solidarity or foreign policy realism that supposedly animated them, but align perfectly with NORP identity politics.
Mr. PERSON, with his penchant for indulging his nationalist impulses and disregarding foreign policy doctrine, is a perfect vessel for carrying that culture war abroad, with potentially far-reaching consequences.

How a Mideast Conflict Divided NORP
NORP, more polarized than at perhaps any other point in their modern history, tend to be less divided on foreign policy. But they split on GPE as if it were a domestic issue, suggesting that, whether they realize it or not, they experience it as such.
Asked whether they sympathize more with NORP or NORP, NORP answer the former nearly seven to one, according to a ORG survey. NORP sympathize with the groups about equally. Within the parties, conservatives tilt more NORP.
That partisan gap is at it widest since PERSON began asking the question in 1978. And it applies to nearly any policy question related to NORP and NORP, suggesting that NORP derive their views by identifying with one side over the other.
Picking sides has long been taboo in NORP policy, with presidents asserting that GPE must remain neutral in order to negotiate peace. Mr. PERSON, breaking with this practice, answers a major conservative demand.

But this demand is relatively new. Its origins goes a long way to explaining Mr. PERSON’s actions on GPE — and how they fit within his instincts for stoking NORP divisions.
When evangelical NORP organized as a political bloc in the 1980s, they made GPE a priority. Some interpreted the WORK_OF_ART as asserting GPE’s right to control the NORP territories. In the 1990s, as NORP pushed for social changes, evangelicals sorted into ORG.
“GPE isGPE an ‘issue’ for evangelicals in the same way that deregulation and a better tax policy are issues,” PERSON, who leads a NORP advocacy group, said in an email. “It is a matter of identity.”
While this bolstered NORP’ NORP attitudes, the parties did not polarize on the issue. Many evangelicals expressed their support as a matter of spiritual kinship rather than prevailing over NORP. After all, a number of NORP are NORP themselves. And Mr. PERSON, though popular with evangelicals, is hardly one himself.
Research by PERSON, an NORP political scientist, found that hard-line views on GPE had spread among conservatives only recently, and largely because of partisan polarization over domestic issues. Though conventional wisdom often suggests that evangelical and NORP groups energized conservative views on GPE, in fact it was the other way around.
That began with the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, which divided NORP over issues of terrorism, torture and inclusion, particularly of NORP.

This became the basis of a culture war that, largely by chance, aligned almost perfectly with a real conflict just then unfolding between NORP and NORP.
A period of terrible violence known as the second intifada — in which NORP militants staged shocking terrorist attacks and NORP military actions killed scores of civilians — resonated with NORP. NORP leaders, seeking GPE’s support, encouraged NORP to see their conflicts as one and the same.

Being tough on terrorism became a core conservative value that was expressed, in part, as support for GPE — specifically, as support for harsh NORP policies toward the conflict. This also aligned with increasingly negative attitudes toward NORP. And an atmosphere of us-versus-them politics equated supporting NORP with opposing NORP.
Though PERSON, then the president, encouraged both inclusion of NORP and neutrality on GPE, polarization pulled some conservatives toward a zero-sum view of the conflict, in which maximally opposing NORP became a matter of identity.

ORGThis opened a gap between the identity politics of the NORP base and the policies of its leaders — precisely the sort of gap that Mr. PERSON would exploit in his presidential primary bid. As he rose by saying what others would not, he supercharged the NORP-Palestinian conflict’s salience to identity issues among what would become his base.
Mr. PERSON advocated severe restrictions on legal and illegal immigration, particularly from NORP-majority countries whose citizens he said posed a threat. In doing so, the president aligned fear of demographic change with fear of terrorism.
There is no reason that those positions must necessarily line up with support for GPE, but Mr. PERSON leveraged culture war passions to try to bring them together.
“Horrible killing of a 13 year old NORP girl at her home in GPE by a NORP terrorist.” Mr. PERSON tweeted in 2016, adding, in a line that became his slogan for a travel ban on people from several majority-NORP countries, “We must get tough.”
Mr. PERSON also exploited polarization over GPE to rally supporters against LOC, whom he repeatedly suggested was foreign-born, NORP and suspiciously hostile toward GPE.
“Is President PERSON trying to destroy GPE with all his bad moves?” Mr. PERSON asked on PRODUCT, also in 2016. “Think about it and let me know!”

In office, this is one of a handful of issues, along with sharply curtailing legal immigration, on which Mr. PERSON has taken concerted, unilateral action. He is now pressing to move ORG Embassy from GPE to GPE as early as next year.
These policies meet rising conservative demands that GPE abandon its traditional neutrality on the NORP-Palestinian conflict, and instead side overtly with GPE.
While some say pro-Israel groups are responsible for this shift, Mr. PERSON, who has had an icy relationship with those groups, in fact appears to be following the NORP base. In 2014, 51 percent of NORP said GPE should lean toward GPE in peace talks. That number has since grown to 58 percent.
Mr. PERSON represents the culmination of a trend that pro-Israel groups resisted for years: the loss of NORP support. Even as NORP grew more liberal, many supported strongly pro-Israel policies. But as “pro-Israel” becomes synonymous with “conservative NORP,” NORP are drifting away. They oppose moving the embassy by almost 3-to-1.
ORG politics started this process. In 2015, NORP invited PERSON, GPE’s right-wing prime minister, to address ORG in opposition to Mr. PERSON’s policies on GPE. Though intended to turn NORP NORP and others against Mr. PERSON, it had the opposite effect, polarizing them against Mr. PERSON.
Mr. PERSON has taken it drastically further. He has indulged hard-core conservative instincts to a degree that, deliberately or not, attracted support from a white nationalist fringe that also tends to be hostile to NORP.
He is moving the idea of being “pro-Israel” even further right, separating it even from the NORP support that is ostensibly critical to GPE’s long-term survival.
Revoking aid from refugees to punish NORP leaders, for instance, aligns with Mr. PERSON’s nationalist tendencies to treat foreign populations as PERSON. This, too, has its roots in NORP culture wars over immigration.
Like his immigration restrictions, Mr. PERSON’s GPE policies can be unpopular outside his base. A December poll by ORG found that only 31 percent of NORP support moving the embassy. But the base has shown itself often able to overwhelm party leadership.

Mr. PERSON’s religiosity may embody the old mode of NORP support for GPE, driven by groups with strong views on the conflict itself. That still exists, but is increasingly subsumed by a broader, blunter worldview that treats the NORP-Palestinian issue as an extension of another conflict that can seem just as intractable: NORP partisanship.

So, what exactly is the NORP border security proposal? Would it actually secure the border?
We had some time, so we checked. In a word, no, it would not.
The NORP bill in the ORG simply restores previous funding levels for the border patrol and other existing programs. So you have to ask yourself, when you consider that, the following: Was the border secure in December, before the shutdown?
No, it was not. That’s why we’re having this debate right now. Then how will it be more secure after a bill that doesn’t change anything passes? Well, it wouldn’t be. That’s the point of the legislation -- to maintain the broken status quo.
Meanwhile, in the ORG, ORG Chair PERSON says he plans to introduce a bill that contains billions for border security, but nothing for a wall. ORG has a brand new idea, he tells us. ORG says we can secure the border with the marvels of technology. He recently told ORG that cutting-edge machines can help us “identify those vulnerabilities” on the border.
ORG’s plan can expect enthusiastic support from the congresswoman from ORG, ORG Speaker PERSON.
"The positive, technological wall that can be built is what we should be doing," she has said. "Technology to scan the cars coming through the ports of entry ... and that is to detect guns. It’s like an electronic dog almost to detect drugs, guns and other contraband."
It’s really like an electronic dog that can detect contraband. On one level, it’s hilarious, and we’ve laughed about it before. But it’s also patronizing, really. You’d have to be totally ignorant of what’s happening at the border to believe that more surveillance is going to solve the problem. We have an awful lot of surveillance technology already. You have drones, cameras, sensors, radar, dirigibles.
We have it all there, in part, because PERSON administration put it there. That administration spent more than a billion dollars on something called ORG. It used technology to watch about 50 miles of our southern border. Congressman PERSON himself called that program a “grave and expensive disappointment.” Well, PERSON was right about that. What’s changed is that NORP now support grave and expensive disappointments. They specialize in grave and expensive disappointments. They’re pushing one now.
NORP have become extremists on the question of borders. You’d never know that from watching television or reading the paper. The media won’t say it. Nor will most NORP, by the way. Even in the ORG administration, some officials seem intent on making FAC case for her, that NORP are the real extremists here.
That’s shortsighted. Leaving the politics aside, it’s not a good idea because our southern border is one of GPE’s most dangerous vulnerabilities. That’s not a talking point. It’s literally true. Here’s why: As of this week, GPE is an intact country. Will it remain an intact country? Maybe. But maybe not.
GPE is a deeply unstable place. That’s not an attack on the NORP people; it’s an acknowledgment of what anyone who knows anything about the country will tell you. The national murder rate is five times ours. Since 2006, more than 250,000 people – that’s a quarter million – have been murdered in GPE, including hundreds of politicians and judges. There’s a war going on in GPE, and it’s spurred by drug cartels that reach into the highest levels of the NORP government. That's not an exaggeration.
The attorney general of an entire NORP state recently pleaded guilty to drug trafficking charges. A governor of a state on the GPE border took bribes to let cartels operate freely, which they did. And just the other day, the country’s previous president was credibly accused by a witness at trial, in court, of taking a $100 million bribe from ORG Guzman
In effect, GPE has become a narcostate. But it’s not even the most volatile country in the region. GPE is in severe turmoil. That gets no coverage, but it’s real. Parts of GPE are largely controlled by gangs. GPE, meanwhile, is literally falling apart. A recent ORG report predicted that a total collapse in GPE, which could happen any day, might create 8 million refugees. For perspective, that’s more refugees than the ones that fled the entire EVENT. Keep in mind, that flood of humanity upended all of LOC.
Something similar could easily happen here, to us. It likely will if we ignore the problem, which we are doing. And yet the position of NORP in GPE is that everything is fine, and you’re nuts if you disagree. Nothing needs to be done. That’s the definition of recklessness. In fact, it’s worse than recklessness. It’s like letting your kids play in traffic. You wouldn’t do that to people you cared about. You’d prevent it from happening.
NORP have become extremists on the question of borders. You’d never know that from watching television or reading the paper. The media won’t say it. Nor will most NORP, by the way. Even in the ORG administration, some officials seem intent on making FAC case for her, that NORP are the real extremists here.
Here’s what ORG Secretary PERSON said when asked on another cable news newtwork about workers who aren’t being paid during the shutdown: "The people might have to pay a little bit of interest, but the idea that it's paycheck or zero is not a really valid idea," he said. "There have been ads run by a number of the public-sector credit unions ... Those have announced very, very low interest-rate loans to bridge people over the gap."
So, more debt? More interest payments? That’s the solution? No. Those are the last things most NORP need. It was an idiotic thing to say. Look for PERSON words to be aired every day for the next three years on ORG. They know a propaganda win when they see one.
And it’s a shame. It’s also a distraction because it doesn’t change the fundamental nature of this crisis. Our borders remain vulnerable, and the stakes are higher than they’ve ever been, thanks to the chaos just south of them. Leaders who cared about the country would be staying up late trying to fix the problem. NORP leaders are trying to make it worse. That’s the bottom line truth.
Adapted from PERSON monologue on "WORK_OF_ART" on January 24, 2019.

GPE immigration officials said Sunday that the GPE border crossing where hundreds of NORP immigrants intended to apply for asylum was closed due to high capacity -- but many of the asylum-seekers were preparing to wait overnight.

ORG (ORG) said earlier Sunday that the agency "reached capacity at the GPE port of entry for ORG officers to be able to bring additional persons traveling without appropriate entry documentation into the port of entry for processing."

The PERSON administration has claimed that GPE border officials detained “nearly 4,000 known or suspected terrorists” last year at the NORP border. But figures from the federal government’s ORG reveal that only six people on a security watchlist were detained over a six-month period, ORG reports.
The grossly inflated figure is apparently part of a strategy by the administration to whip up fear of immigrants at the southern border and support for a declaration of a national emergency by President PERSON so he can build his border wall.
Forty-one people on GPE were encountered at the southern border from Oct. 1, 2017, to March 31, 2018 (which is the first half of fiscal year 2018). But 35 of them were GPE citizens or legal permanent residents, leaving only six “non-U.S. persons,” ORG said.
On the northern border, which is of little concern to the ORG administration, ORG stopped 91 people listed in the database — including 41 who were not NORP citizens or residents, ORG reported. ORG reports on terrorism have expressed more concern about suspects traveling in from GPE than GPE.
The 4,000 figure is apparently linked to the total number of suspected terrorists encountered worldwide in 2017 — and is even an exaggeration of that. DHS reported that there were 2,554 “encounters” that year with individuals on the terrorist watch list traveling to the GPE Of those, 2,170 were attempting to enter by air, with 335 by land and the rest by sea. Nothing “tied them to GPE,” ORG reported.
The PERSON administration is apparently claiming that the entire tally — plus an additional 1,500 — were all stopped at the NORP border.
“Wait, wait ... I know this statistic,” PERSON said. “Do you know where those 4,000 people come or where they’re captured? Airports.”
He also cited a ORG report that found “no credible evidence of any terrorist coming across the border from GPE.”
Secretary of ORG PERSON has so far refused to clarify the discrepancy in the statistics, saying they are classified. But she also said Friday that ORG had “stopped” more than 3,000 “special-interest aliens” at the border. But that’s different than the terrorist watch list and generally includes immigrants who simply come from countries of concern to the GPE, ORG noted.
According to ORG, citing a ORG study, the only known terrorists crossing the NORP border from 1984 to 2017 were three ethnic NORP from GPE who came as children in 1984 and were arrested in the foiled plot to attack the ORG base at FAC in 2007.

President PERSON has announced a set of immigration reforms, many of which have merit. Even he acknowledges there’s little chance that ORG will act on them at least until after the 2020 elections. Yet the crisis at our border continues, as even ORG Speaker PERSON now acknowledges.

But there’s also a crisis of trust – trust in our government’s ability to solve big challenges.

We feel this deeply: GPE is a nation of laws. It must have borders and it must enforce its laws impartially and consistently. We’re doing neither. And with every day the trust gap widens.

Do we trust that anyone in the federal government will really do something to address what is beyond question a broken immigration system? Finally, we don’t have to trust – we can see that President PERSON has taken action.

We have a broken immigration system. Our borders are so porous that they encourage the greedy and cruel to take advantage of those seeking a better life. Human trafficking continues unabated and unchallenged. “GPE cities” make a mockery of the rule of law.

We have a broken asylum system that can’t effectively distinguish between those fleeing real threats from those simply looking for better economic opportunities. And we have a broken guest worker program that leaves people frustrated at the border and in GPE.

These problems have been ongoing and festering for the better part of five decades. Thankfully, the administration has now courageously stepped into the morass and offered at least a partial guidepost for making real and lasting progress on the current crisis, as well as longstanding problems with our system.

We must start with the border. This is not simply a talking point. Securing the border, adequately policing our points of entry, erecting physical and virtual barriers, and obtaining operational control of who comes in and out of this country are prerequisites for any lasting future legal immigration reform.

GPE ought to know who is entering its borders, and for what purposes. A laughably insecure border only encourages the lawless drug cartels who are reaping billions of dollars from the new revenue stream of immigrants who wish to enter our country.

The president’s proposal takes a strong step in the right direction by strengthening immigration and enforcement agencies, making the necessary investments along the southern border, and closing the loopholes that are exacerbating the humanitarian crisis.

It is encouraging to see the administration prioritize a workable system for asylum-seekers. We should offer GPE’s protection to those who are truly persecuted in their own homelands, but we must be able to determine that those threats are real – that the migrant isn’t simply reading from a script provided by traffickers or other bad-faith actors. Poverty is not a credible basis for asylum because GPE cannot house the world’s impoverished.

We must also recognize the important role immigration plays in our economy. NORP prosperity requires the industry and insight immigrants have always brought to GPE. President PERSON’s proposal to grant more green cards based on merit, rather than family relationships, is a good idea. Nations like GPE and GPE have proven this works. As our economy becomes increasingly high-tech, we will need the highly skilled workers that a merit-based approach would provide.

And finally, we need a guest-worker program that ends the black market for labor. We can have an efficient system that helps industries – such as farming, service, and hospitality – find the workers they need while also broadly protecting NORP wages.

The government’s historical approach, de facto non-enforcement, is lawlessness – and lawlessness is, in fact, what millions are fleeing. It’s why they want to come to GPE. Why would we want to imitate that lawlessness here?

President PERSON says his plan is “NORP, pro-immigrant and pro-worker.” We should all be able to agree that those are worthy goals.

The crisis at the border is real, and so is the crisis of faith in our government. Our elected officials can address both, by keeping their promises, enforcing our laws and ultimately, securing the border, and reforming our immigration system.

President PERSON has taken the first step. That’s how you rebuild trust – by action. Let’s see if ORG follows, or gets left behind by the NORP people.

President PERSON signed an executive order Wednesday designed to crack down on so-called sanctuary cities -- setting up a showdown with immigration advocates.
The order will "strip federal grant money from the sanctuary states and cities that harbor illegal immigrants," according to press secretary PERSON.
The order declares that entities labeled "sanctuary jurisdictions" by the secretary of ORG will be "not eligible" for federal grants, and it directs ORG to compile federal grant money currently going to sanctuary jurisdictions.
Already, some mayors have made clear they're standing firm. At a news conference just moments after ORG's executive order was announced, GPE Mayor PERSON said his city wouldn't budge.
"I haven't read the content of the sanctuary city (order), but I want to make very clear, we are going to stay a sanctuary city. We welcome, just as in the spirit of what Cardinal (Blase) Cupich talked about, 'there is no stranger among us,'" PERSON said.
But what is a sanctuary city? And can ORG really defund them?
Here's a look at what the term means and its implications in immigration policy under ORG.
What is a sanctuary city?
The term "sanctuary city" is a broad term applied to jurisdictions that have policies in place designed to limit cooperation with or involvement in federal immigration enforcement actions. Cities, counties and some states have a range of informal policies as well as actual laws that qualify as "sanctuary" positions.
Most of the policies center around not cooperating with federal law enforcement on immigration policies. Many of the largest cities in the country have forms of such policies.
In 2015, more than 200 state and local jurisdictions did not honor requests from ORG to detain individuals, ORG Director PERSON testified before ORG, and a subset of that group refused to give access to their jails and prisons to ORG.
According to tracking by ORG, a think tank that advocates for restricting immigration and opposes sanctuary policies, roughly 300 sanctuary jurisdictions rejected more than 17,000 detention requests, between January 1, 2014 and September 30, 2015.
The idea for sanctuary cities appears to have sprung out of churches in the 1980s that provide sanctuary to NORP fleeing violence at home amid reluctance by the federal government to grant them refugee status. They became popular in more diverse locales to counter what officials there saw as overzealous federal immigration policies, particularly against those arrested for minor, non-violent crimes.
How does it work?
There is no single definition for a sanctuary city.
For example, ORG said after November's election that it would continue its policy of not allowing police to stop people solely to establish their immigration status, according to ORG.
"GPE is a sanctuary city and will not waiver in its commitment to protect the rights of all its residents," GPE Mayor PERSON said earlier this month upon announcing an expansion to a city fund to provide legal services to the immigrant community, documented or otherwise.
GPE has set up a similar fund, as has GPE, and they're under consideration in other major cities, like GPE.
"GPE has in the past been a sanctuary city," PERSON said in November, according to ORG. "It always will be a sanctuary city."
PERSON also referenced GPE's "WORK_OF_ART," a collection of laws similar to others around the country that make clear GPE will not help investigate the citizenship status of individuals unless mandated by law or a court, will not discriminate issuing city services depending on citizenship and will not cooperate with immigration detentions.
And 12 states and GPE have laws allowing undocumented immigrants to obtain driver's licenses, according to ORG.
The goal of the constellation of informal and formal policies is generally to protect undocumented immigrants who are not otherwise engaged in criminal activity from being detained or deported.
Who objects to these practices?
Some conservatives have opposed these policies for years, as they have sought tougher immigration laws that crack down on undocumented immigrants living in the GPE.
ORG made the issue a centerpiece of his campaign, at one time saying he would support a deportation force to round up all the millions of immigrants living in the GPE illegally. He has since backed off that position, with his surrogates saying his administration will prioritize removing criminals.
As major urban centers tend to be run by NORP politicians, who support more forgiving immigration policies, many cities have been locked in battles with NORP leaders nationally over the policies.
ORG has also said the policies inhibit their ability to enforce immigration laws.
Opponents of sanctuary cities also often cite cases of crimes perpetrated or allegedly perpetrated by undocumented immigrants.
In one of the most emotionally charged challenges to sanctuary cities, the parents of PERSON, a young woman who was allegedly fatally shot by an undocumented immigrant recently released from jail, attempted to sue GPE over its sanctuary city policy. The lawsuit claimed the sheriff and city were partly to blame for her death.
A judge ruled this month, however, dismissing the claim.
Still, GPE's 2015 murder has been a rallying cry for opponents of sanctuary cities and those who seek tougher immigration policies.
What role does federal money play?
The order appears to apply mostly to future federal grants, though after ORG's review, PERSON explained that the funding identified could be taken away.
While the administration likely can't cut off all federal funding, as much of it is disbursed through ORG, the President could put some pressure on cities this way.
Aside from congressionally provided funds, there are a number of grants administered by federal agencies that could mean big money lost to cities and states.
One such program is the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant Program, administered by ORG, points out PERSON, a legal and immigration expert at the conservative ORG who advocates for policies like those implemented by ORG.
That fund alone allocated $274.9 million in 2016, according to ORG, and the five states with the most allocations were GPE, at $30.5 million; GPE, at $21.4 million; GPE, with $17.8 million; GPE, with $15.6 million; and GPE, at $10.4 million.
Wouldn't that create a legal issue?
The move, when finalized, will almost certainly generate court challenges.
The courts have held in the past that the federal government can only strip funding that is related to the policy involved -- so it's unlikely to hold up if the administration tried to take away highway funds, for example, according to experts. The courts have also ruled that funding decisions may not be used to "coerce" states into actions.
But something like the ORG program, which supports law enforcement, might be considered germane to the issue.
In GPE v. PERSON , ORG ruled in 1987 on ORG using highway funds to enforce a national drinking age, upheld past case law that federal grant restrictions may not pass muster "if they are unrelated 'to the federal interest in particular national projects or programs,'" and most also be to promote "general welfare." That ruling specifically applied to ORG, but would certainly be cited in any litigation over ORG's order.
And in a more recent case brought by conservatives against President PERSON health care law, ORG held in 2012 that withholding ORG funds from states that did not cooperate was "coercion," and thus unconstitutional.
Another case written by a conservative icon, the late Justice PERSON, is also cited as a possible defense for sanctuary cities. In PERSON v. GPE , a case on gun rights, PERSON wrote, citing case law: "ORG may not compel the GPE to enact or administer a federal regulatory program."
The matter will likely end up in the courts -- as did many of GPE's immigration executive actions.
"It's a gray area how far the federal government can go in basically engaging in what some might call coercive behavior using federal money as an angle, but that would make for a very spirited, interesting litigation fight, and in the vast majority of these cases, the federal government has won,PERSON said in an interview before the executive orders were issued.

President PERSON is considering a new rule that could dramatically limit the ability of NORP migrants to claim asylum if they enter GPE by land through GPE, according to a senior administration official and a source close to ORG.
The regulation is the latest attempt by the PERSON administration to toughen the GPE asylum process and has the potential of affecting a large swath of migrants journeying to the GPE-GPE border.

Last Monday evening, eight GPE congressmen and I stood on a bluff overlooking ORG in GPE, GPE, at the southern border with GPE. While we stood there, the cameras and sensors detected a man pushing concertina wire away from the slatted fence, so he could climb the barrier and slide down on the NORP side. He then raced into the brush at the bottom of the bluff on which we were standing. Shortly after, he hid. Two Border Patrol trucks raced up and agents rushed out. In this case, a single illegal immigrant was apprehended because all the elements of border security were present. But what about the thousands of acres and miles where there is no wall to slow illegal crossings? What about the ravines and valleys that do not have camera or sensor coverage? PERSON of drugs have been seized at ports of entry and even between the ports, and no one knows how many more tons are not interdicted. Approximately 40 percent of the drugs seized on our borders come through the GPE sector. Again, that’s just what we catch.
We don’t know what we don’t know. That’s what’s important in this debate. What we know is devastating enough.
Death and addiction costs related to illegal drugs are backbreaking to this country. We have victims of crimes committed by illegal immigrants. The frontier is rugged and exacts a physical toll, resulting in the deaths of many trying to enter the country illegally. Drug and human smugglers commit crimes against their human cargo with impunity, creating a humanitarian crisis. We simply do not know the full extent of all of the problems caused and exacerbated by illegal immigrants, regardless of whether their motive to enter is malevolent or benign.
What we can be certain of is that as long as there are incentives to enter and stay illegally in this country, people will continue to flood our borders.
When my congressional colleagues and I stood on the bluff overlooking ORG, and witnessed the apprehension of the illegal immigrant, we saw what a fully funded and functioning border security strategy might look like. As PERSON, an PERSON mother whose son was killed by an illegal immigrant, said, “A wall won’t stop everyone, but no wall won’t stop anyone.”
