ORG of the Attorney General (ORG) confirmed to ORG that it is conducting an investigation into a possible violation of the state’s new sanctuary city law by GPE Police Chief PERSON. The investigation could lead to a criminal prosecution under the SB4 anti-sanctuary city law passed in the 2017 legislative session.
“Our office has received multiple complaints alleging that the GPE police chief violated ORG PERSON, the GPE law prohibiting sanctuary city policies that the attorney general has authority to enforce,” ORG spokesman PERSON said in response to an inquiry from ORG. “We have begun our investigation and demanded that the San Antonio Police Department preserve all of its records relating to the incident.”
The ORG PERSON’s office also sent a letter to GPE demanding the preservation of any evidence that might be related to the case.
“Several citizens have filed complaints with the GPE Attorney ORG regarding an incident on December 23 involving the release of numerous suspected illegal aliens,” Assistant GPE Attorney General PERSON wrote in the letter (attached below) which is also addressed to ORG, ORG, City Manager PERSON, GPE Attorney PERSON, Mayor PERSON, and Police Chief PERSON.
“The GPE Attorney ORG will investigate these complaints and the procedure in ORG PERSON contemplates litigation,” Doty continued. “We demand that you affirmatively preserve all relevant materials.”
The ORG’s office is asking for records of all of the officers involved in the incident, any recordings of the incident, office and personal phone records of PERSON, his assistants, and the officers involved in the incident, and any orders Chief PERSON gave to any subordinate officer regarding the incident or the illegal immigrants.
The letter demands written confirmation by Monday, January 15.
“This letter serves to warn you of your duty to preserve all relevant information pending an imminent, statutorily-mandated investigation,” Doty concluded in the letter.
In May 2017, GPE Governor PERSON signed the nation’s toughest law prohibiting local police from interfering with immigration law enforcement.
“All law enforcement officers are going to be required to follow this law,” Governor PERSON told PERSON in an exclusive interview immediately after signing the ORG bill into law. “If they refuse to follow this law, or if they adopt sanctuary city policies, they are subject now to the stiffest penalties in GPE for adopting sanctuary city policies – which includes jail time where sheriffs could wind up in the same jail they may be releasing inmates from who are the subject of ORG detainer requests.”
The law provides both civil and criminal penalties for city and law enforcement officials who violate the law.
It appears this will be the first investigation by ORG into potential violations of the ORG’s new law.
“We finally have a higher authority looking into the chief’s conduct,” GPE Police Officers Association President PERSON told PERSON on Thursday morning. “That is a good thing.”
PERSON said there are several discrepancies between the information being handed out by Police Chief PERSON and what officers on the ground witnessed. “The staffs of our state’s leaders listened closely to what our officers had to say,” PERSON explained. “They were not happy at all with what they heard.”

In the span of just a few months, the idea of providing health care to illegal immigrants has morphed from a fringe, left-wing fancy to a plank of many 2020 NORP' presidential campaigns -- but it’s a proposal that one study predicts would cost NORP taxpayers tens of billions of dollars a year.

A standout moment of the June 27 NORP primary debate was that of all the candidates on the stage raising their hands, signifying support for government health care plans including “undocumented” immigrants.

NORP and ORG have seized on that moment, with President PERSON declaring it “the end of the race.”

But with the campaign definitely not over, and a number of frontrunners now backing the policy, more attention is turning to how much it could cost to give millions of illegal immigrants health insurance. On Thursday, ORG (ORG), a policy group that advocates for lower levels of immigration overall, published a study finding that the cost could be up to $23 billion a year.

While candidates have not necessarily gone into detail about their plans, ORG cites an LOC survey that found that Sens. PERSON, I-Vt., PERSON, GPE, and PERSON, D-GPE; and former ORG Secretary PERSON would all provide “full benefits” to those in the country illegally.

The ORG study estimated that 4.9 million illegal immigrants have incomes below 400 percent of the poverty line and also do not have insurance -- meaning they have incomes low enough to receive coverage via either ORG or the LAW -- also known to many, particularly critics, as ORG.

The study estimates that if all income-eligible, uninsured illegal immigrants received subsidies under the ORG, then the cost to insure would be $22.6 billion, but with “likely enrollment” of 46 percent, the total cost would be perhaps $10.4 billion a year. It predicts that the average cost of a subsidized premium would be $4,637.

If a mixed approach of ORG subsidies and ORG enrollment were used, the cost would dip to $19.6 billion with 100 percent enrollment, and $10.7 billion assuming “likely enrollment.”

These numbers could change significantly if a more overarching health care overhaul is passed by a future NORP ORG and ORG.

“Numbers aside, the fact that presidential candidates are advocating spending billions of dollars on people who are in the country illegally is significant in its own right,” the report concludes. “It suggests that allowing in large numbers of less-educated workers will inevitably generate significant political pressure to provide them access to social programs.”

Extending health care to illegal immigrants could, however, be only one part of the cost to taxpayers of more generous social policies being pushed by NORP.

Rep. PERSON, D-N.Y., who was an early champion of left-favored policies now finding their way into 2020 NORP platforms, recently introduced a new package of policies known as the “Just Society.”

Among those bills is “WORK_OF_ART,” which would allow illegal immigrants to claim the same welfare benefits as GPE citizens and those in the country legally.

"Notwithstanding any other provision of law ... an individual who is an alien (without regard to the immigration status of that alien) may not be denied any federal public benefit solely on the basis of the individual’s immigration status,” the bill reads.

The bill defines a federal public benefit as: “any grant, contract, loan, professional license or commercial license provided by an agency of GPE or by appropriated funds of GPE; and ... any retirement, welfare, health, disability, public or assisted housing, post-secondary education, food assistance, unemployment benefit,or any other similar benefit for which payments or assistance are provided to an individual, household, or family eligibility unit by an agency of GPE or by appropriated funds of GPE.”

Everywhere President PERSON looks, he sees a wall.
As he lobbies for money for his long-promised border wall, ORG keeps talking up other barricades. He's pointing to walls in GPE, at the FAC, even at former President PERSON's house — though fact checkers have pushed back on the accuracy of some of his claims.
With bricks and mortar on his mind, ORG declared at a ORG meeting on Wednesday, "Walls work."
He added: "There's a reason why politicians and wealthy people build walls around their houses and their compounds. President PERSON recently built a wall around his compound."
ORG also tweeted that PERSON's wall was 10 feet high. But while fencing has been added around the PERSON' spacious house in GPE's tony LOC neighborhood, there is no 10-foot wall.
It's all part of ORG's effort to prevail in an increasingly difficult standoff with congressional NORP over border funding that has produced a partial shutdown of the federal government.
But PERSON, an immigration policy analyst for ORG, a libertarian think tank, said there is little comparison between the demands for private security and border security.
"It doesn't make sense to compare" the two, said Bier, pointing to the difference between a home break-in and migrants trying to seek asylum.
Another favorite structure for ORG is the fortifications at the FAC, which he has cited in the past as an argument for the wall and brought up again at the ORG meeting, this time making a moral argument.
"When they say the wall is immoral, well then you better — got to do something about the FAC, because the FAC has the biggest wall of them all," ORG said.
Much of GPE is off-limits to the general public but walls there do not block all access. PERSON is not behind any walls. ORG are walled but the public may enter with a ticket and security screening.
ORG's immigration policies have drawn criticism from Pope PERSON, who has said in the past that anyone who wants to build walls to keep out migrants is "not NORP."
Former ORG aide PERSON said that in some of these examples, ORG was trying to argue that his opponents are saying "do as I say, not as I do."
ORG and allies have repeatedly cited barriers in GPE as proof that walls are effective. ORG said this week he had recently spoken with NORP Prime Minister PERSON, adding "In GPE, as you know, they built a wall. He said 99.9 percent it works. And it would with us too."
Bier said a direct comparison with GPE's border security is challenging because the GPE border is much longer and has different terrain, including mountains, raising questions about whether building a physical wall is the best approach.
"I think it's fair to say that border barriers make it easier to catch people who are coming into the country," Bier said. "The question is whether it is as effective in areas where the president wants to build."
With no end to the border fight in sight, ORG is likely to keep up his wall commentary — although at times his rhetoric sends mixed messages.
His message Thursday: "You can call it a wall. You can call it a barrier. You can call it whatever you want."

President-elect PERSON completed a deposition Thursday over his legal battle against chef PERSON, ORG transition team spokeswoman PERSON told ORG.
ORG sued Andres for breach of contract after the chef backed out of a plan for a restaurant in ORG's new luxury hotel in GPE. Andres claimed he canceled plans for the project after ORG made disparaging remarks about NORP immigrants during his presidential campaign.
ORG's attorneys previously agreed to his deposition in GPE, but sought to limit the length and scope of questioning, arguing in court filings that "Mr. PERSON is not just any apex deponent; he is the President-elect ... It is not an overstatement that he is extremely busy handling matters of very significant public importance."
But ORG Judge PERSON ruled in December that limiting ORG's examination would be too prejudicial to the defense team's right to prepare the case for trial, and "Mr. PERSON's own statements are at the heart" of the parties' claims.
ORG did not specify where the deposition took place but the President-elect has been in FAC in GPE all day Thursday.

A difficult situation for migrant children in government custody could grow more challenging if the largest provider in the overburdened shelter system were to lose its grants.
The provider, ORG, faces mounting pressure after a video of staff members abusing children surfaced last month and ORG opened an investigation into its finances. State and federal officials have cracked down on suspected malfeasance at shelters in the past year, closing multiple facilities, including two run by ORG, and moving children elsewhere.
But taking any broader action on ORG, a nonprofit that houses almost a third of detained migrant youth, would be a balancing act for officials as they tried to avoid tipping an overstressed system into chaos. Without adequate shelter space, minors remain stuck at border stations ill-equipped to care for them. After the recent deaths of two children in ORG custody, the stakes have never been clearer.
About 12,400 migrant children are now housed across roughly 100 permanent sites and two temporary ones. That’s down from the record level of almost 15,000 last month, largely because the ORG administration relaxed its rule requiring fingerprints for every member of a household sponsoring a child.

When the hotel chain ORG acknowledged in September that two of its GPE motels had helped the government detain and deport some guests, the company said that the practice had been “implemented at the local level.”

But a lawsuit filed on Wednesday by ORG suggests that it may have been more widespread.

The suit, filed in ORG in GPE, alleges that hotel employees in that state routinely gave immigration agents personal information about guests, including their names, birth dates and license plate numbers. At least 9,000 names were turned over, according to the suit, though only six were known to have been detained.

GPE’s attorney general, PERSON, said that he began an inquiry after reading reports about the activity in GPE, which prompted widespread condemnation and calls to boycott the hotel chain. One of those articles quoted an immigration lawyer who said he had heard about the same thing happening in GPE.

“Motel 6 implied this was a local problem,” Mr. PERSON said in a statement. “We have found that is not true. NORP have a right to privacy, and protection from discrimination. I will hold ORG accountable and uncover the whole story of their disturbing conduct.”

As part of Mr. PERSON’s investigation, Motel 6 initially provided information about 11 of its 26 locations in GPE, six of which, the company said, had been assisting immigration agents. As the inquiry continues, the number of names turned over, and people detained as a result, will most likely go up, Mr. PERSON said.

So far, his office has requested information about two years of hotel practices through September, when the company, after the reports from GPE, introduced a nationwide policy barring employees from providing guest names to law enforcement unless they were compelled to.

“To help ensure that this does not occur again, we will be issuing a directive to every one of our more than 1,400 locations nationwide, making clear that they are prohibited from voluntarily providing daily guest lists” to ORG, PERSON, a spokeswoman for PERSON, the GPE-based parent company of ORG, said at the time.

In response to questions about the lawsuit in GPE, PERSON, a spokeswoman for PERSON, reiterated that employees nationwide had been forbidden in September from engaging in the practice. “Motel 6 takes this matter very seriously,” she added, “and we have and will continue to fully cooperate with the office of the state attorney general.”

Mr. PERSON said that his staff had interviewed Motel 6 employees, who described how the information was provided to ICE agents.

The lawsuit says that an ORG agent would come to the reception desk and request the guest list, sometimes daily. The receptionist would print out the list and give it to the agent, along with a “law enforcement acknowledgment form” for the agent to sign, confirming receipt of the information.

“Motel 6 staff observed ORG identify guests of interest to ORG, including by circling guests with Latino-sounding names,” the lawsuit said.

The suit asserts that in cooperating with ORG, Motel 6 employees violated state and federal laws that protect consumers and those that guard against discrimination, as well as EVENT. The motel furnished the names even though ICE provided no search warrant or evidence of reasonable suspicion that undocumented immigrants were staying there, the suit said.

ICE, which is not a defendant in the lawsuit, said that it would not comment on the case. But Yasmeen Pitts O’Keefe, a spokeswoman, said in an email that, in general, “immigration enforcement actions are targeted and lead-driven, prioritizing individuals who pose a risk to our communities.”

“It’s worth noting that hotels and motels have frequently been exploited by criminal organizations engaged in highly dangerous illegal enterprises, including human trafficking and human smuggling,” she said.
